--
-- PostgreSQL database dump

SET statement_timeout = 0;
SET client_encoding = 'UTF8';
SET standard_conforming_strings = on;
SET check_function_bodies = false;
SET client_min_messages = warning;

--
-- Name: plpgsql; Type: EXTENSION; Schema: -; Owner: 
--

CREATE EXTENSION IF NOT EXISTS plpgsql WITH SCHEMA pg_catalog;


--
-- Name: EXTENSION plpgsql; Type: COMMENT; Schema: -; Owner: 
--

COMMENT ON EXTENSION plpgsql IS 'PL/pgSQL procedural language';


SET search_path = public, pg_catalog;

SET default_tablespace = '';

SET default_with_oids = false;

--
-- Name: bib; Type: TABLE; Schema: public; Owner: postgres; Tablespace: 
--

CREATE TABLE bib (
    id bigint NOT NULL,
    description character varying(4096),
    keywords character varying(4096),
    name character varying(255),
    url character varying(255),
    worksheet character varying(255),
    worksheetexists boolean NOT NULL
);


ALTER TABLE public.bib OWNER TO postgres;

--
-- Name: hibernate_sequence; Type: SEQUENCE; Schema: public; Owner: postgres
--

CREATE SEQUENCE hibernate_sequence
    START WITH 1
    INCREMENT BY 1
    NO MINVALUE
    NO MAXVALUE
    CACHE 1;


ALTER TABLE public.hibernate_sequence OWNER TO postgres;

--
-- Name: hibernate_sequence; Type: SEQUENCE SET; Schema: public; Owner: postgres
--

SELECT pg_catalog.setval('hibernate_sequence', 1413, true);

    id bigint NOT NULL,
    edit character varying(255)
);


ALTER TABLE public.mode OWNER TO postgres;

--
-- Name: org; Type: TABLE; Schema: public; Owner: postgres; Tablespace: 
--

CREATE TABLE org (
    id bigint NOT NULL,
    academic boolean NOT NULL,
    affiliations character varying(255),
    code character varying(255),
    contact character varying(255),
    description character varying(4096),
    email character varying(255),
    federal boolean NOT NULL,
    interagency boolean NOT NULL,
    keywords character varying(4096),
    local boolean NOT NULL,
    logo character varying(255),
    name character varying(255),
    ngo boolean NOT NULL,
    otherpartnertype boolean NOT NULL,
    partner boolean NOT NULL,
    program boolean NOT NULL,
    state boolean NOT NULL,
    url character varying(255),
    worksheet character varying(255),
    worksheetexists boolean NOT NULL
);


ALTER TABLE public.org OWNER TO postgres;

215	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	MD16	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	Zoe Johnson, Maryland Department of Natural Resources, ZJohnson@dnr.state.md.us	f	f	f	t	\N	f	f	f	Maryland's Living Shoreline Initiative includes a tool in the Coastal Atlas called the Shoreline Management tool and involves training workshops for contractors, local managers and private landowners on implementing “living shoreline” protection practices to minimize shoreline erosion and protect upland properties. Topics covered have included: site visits and determining if a living shoreline is appropriate, state and county permits, working with a contractor, financial assistance for projects, and more. 216	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	MD17	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	Dana Limpert, Biodiversity Analyst, Maryland Division of Wildlife and Heritage, dlimpert@dnr.state.md.gov	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	Somerset county has good mapping data of terrapin nesting habitat, and Maryland Division of Wildlife and Heritage is using the Sea-Level Affecting Marshes Model data developed as a part of Maryland's Coastal Atlas to see where good nesting habitat might change becasue of sea-level rise.    The Division also used the SLAMM results to look at where future nesting areas might be located and whether there was development nearby or if they could be protected.  SLAMM predicts a decrease of sandy areas with sea-level rise, but one conculsion is that Poplar Island restoration has resulted in an increase in terrapin sandy beach habitat. Thus, this shows that if the Division can stay out ahead of sea-level rise they might be able to restore or create terrapin habitat than will not be affected by sea-level rise.   	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	 Completed Regional Or State Mid-Atlantic Marlyland Natural Ecosystems Inland Habitats and Watersheds  Beaches Biota Marine Terrestrial Conservation/ Restoration of Sensitive Species and Habitats Assess Climate and its Impacts Vulnerability assessments (species, habitats and community vulnerability assessments) Inform Mitigation and Adaptation Choices Ecological and Biological	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	Terrapin Nesting Habitat and Sea-Level Rise	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	Maryland Division of Wildlife and Heritage	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
899	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	NY11	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	Tracey Tomajer, New York State Department of Environmental Conservation, \r\ntmtomaje@gw.dec.state.ny.us\r\n	f	f	f	f	March 2011	f	f	f	From the Executive Summary: Vulnerability assessments are rapidly becoming an essential tool in climate change adaptation planning. As states revise their Wildlife Action Plans, the need to integrate climate change considerations drives the adoption of vulnerability assessments as critical components. To help meet this need for New York, we calculated the relative vulnerability of 119 of New York’s Species of Greatest Conservation Need (SGCN) using NatureServe’s Climate Change Vulnerability Index (CCVI)...The primary factors that drove our assessments included genetic variation, phenological responses, natural and anthropogenic barriers to dispersal, and restriction to specific geological features. Vulnerability was only weakly associated with conservation status. Species at the southern edge of their range in New York might become extirpated from the state. Our results agreed broadly with those from Pennsylvania and West Virginia.  Additional species in need of assessment include plants, crayfish, cave obligates, and functional or habitat groups of species. Our assessment makes several key points: 1) aquatic and terrestrial habitat connectivity must be maintained and restored, 2) for some species, stressors other than climate change are more limiting to their viability; 3) for some species, climate change will likely result in their extirpation no matter what management actions are taken; and 4) long-term monitoring is vital to detecting changes in New York’s wildlife populations."\r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	 Completed Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) Conservation/ Restoration of Sensitive Species and Habitats Regional Or State Mid-Atlantic New York Managed Ecosystems Natural Ecosystems Biota Assess Climate and its Impacts Vulnerability assessments (species, habitats and community vulnerability assessments) Inform Mitigation and Adaptation Choices Plans, Assessments, Studies Vulnerability Assessment	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	Vulnerability of At-Risk Species to Climate Change in New York\r\n	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	New York Natural Heritage Program	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.natureserve.org/prodServices/climatechange/pdfs/ccvi_report_ny.pdf\r\n	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f

236	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	f	NH4	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	Steve Miller, Great Bay NERR, steve.miller@wildlife.nh.gov; Cameron Wake, UNH, Cameron.wake@unh.edu	f	f	f	f	December 2011	f	f	f	This report is a detailed assessment of climate change for coastal New Hampshire that describes how the region's climate has changed over the past century, and how climate may change over the course of this century based on different global greenhouse gas emission scenarios. The impacts of our changing climate are already affecting coastal communities. This report provides decision-relevant information on a regional scale to individual, municipal, regional, and state decision-makers.  The information compiled in the climate assessment provides the foundation for developing local adaptation plans to a changing climate and this project will disseminate this information to seacoast municipalities. Adaptation can help reduce the vulnerability of both natural and social systems to climate change and variability, and can assist with preparing for and coping with negative impacts. Adapting to a changing climate requires both data and information at a spatial and temporal scale that is relevant to decision making. The information compiled in this climate change assessment report, combined with the NHCAW training programs, will provide the foundation for developing local adaptation planning to a changing climate.\r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	 Completed Regional Or State New England New Hampshire Climate Impacts on Water Resources Assess Climate and its Impacts Vulnerability assessments (species, habitats and community vulnerability assessments) Inform Mitigation and Adaptation Choices Translation of Climate Science for Sector/Decision-Maker Use  Physical Atmospheric Coastal and Oceanic Terrestrial (Groundwater, Soil Moisture, surface water, glaciers and ice caps, land cover, biomass) Climate Society Interactions Plans, Assessments, Studies Impact Study Risk and Vulnerability	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	Climate Change in the Piscataqua/Great Bay Region: Past, Present, and Future	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	f	f	f	f	f	Provide decision-relevant information on a regional scale to individual, municipal, regional, and state decision-makers information to assist in adaptation efforts. 200	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	t	MD1	t	f	t	f	f	t	f	t	Chris Cortina, Chesapeake & Coastal Service, Maryland Department of Natural Resources, ccortina@dnr.state.md.us\r\n	f	t	t	t	Completed, but continually updated.	f	f	t	The Coastal Atlas is the result of a collaborative effort among the Maryland Department of Natural Resources, the Maryland Energy Administration, Towson University, the University of Maryland, The Nature Conservancy and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. The data available through the Coastal Atlas includes physical characteristics, human uses and ecological resources. Through the Coastal Atlas, users are able to visualize, query, map, and analyze available data to better manage our marine and estuarine resources. The tools currently available, and those that will be continually developed for the Coastal Atlas, are designed to support better decision-making by transforming available data into information tailored for specific issues.\r\n	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	t	f	t	\N	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	t	f	f	f	 Ongoing Completed Regional Or State Mid-Atlantic Marlyland Public Health and Safety Infrastructure Energy Communication and Commerce Managed Ecosystems Natural Ecosystems Coasts Estuaries Wetlands (e.g., saltwater, brackish, freshwater; 1217	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	Molly Mitchell, Virginia Institute of Marine Science, molly@vims.edu	t	f	f	f	January 2013	f	f	f	The Virginia General Assembly requested that in conducting its study, the Virginia Institute of Marine Science \r\n\r\n- review and develop a comprehensive list of ideas and examples of strategies used in \r\nsimilar settings around the United States and the world; \r\n\r\n- convene a stakeholder advisory panel for the purpose of discussing and assessing the \r\nfeasibility of employing these strategies in Tidewater and Eastern Shore Virginia; and \r\noffer specific recommendations for the detailed investigation of preferred options for \r\nadapting to relative sea-level rise.\r\n\r\nThe study was undertaken with the collaboration and assistance of Old Dominion University, \r\nthe Hampton Roads Planning District Commission, Wetlands Watch, the University of Virginia \r\nInstitute for Environmental Negotiation, the William and Mary Coastal Policy Clinic, and \r\nrelevant state agencies.  Data and analyses were collected from multiple local, state, and \r\nfederal agencies, as well as NGOs and regional authorities.\r\nThis Recurrent Flooding Study addresses all localities in Virginia’s coastal zone.  It documents flooding risks based on available records of past road and infrastructure inundation as well as potential flooding risks based on the best available topographic information.  It assesses future \r\nrisk based on projections for sea level rise from the National Climate Assessment program\r\nmodified to incorporate factors specific to Virginia’s coastal zone.  The study also inventories adaptation options from regional, national, and international sources.  Options include planning, management, and engineering strategies that merit particular consideration for application in Virginia.	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	 Completed Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) Regional Or State Mid-Atlantic Virginia Natural Ecosystems Infrastructure Recreation and Tourism Economic Resources Cross Disciplinary Assess Climate and its Impacts Risk Assessments Inform Mitigation and Adaptation Choices Forecasts of Climate Impacts  Plans, Assessments, Studies Impact Study	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	Recurrent Flooding Study for Tidewater Virginia (SJR 76, 2012) 	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	Virginia Institute of Marine Science,	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	t	t	\N	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://leg2.state.va.us/dls/h&sdocs.nsf/By+Year/SD32013/$file/SD3.pdf	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
204	f	f	t	f	f	t	f	f	t	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	MD5	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	Zoe Johnson, Maryland Department of Natural Resources, ZJohnson@dnr.state.md.us	f	t	f	f	2008	f	f	f	This document represents the first phase of Maryland’s Comprehensive Strategy for Reducing Maryland’s Vulnerability to Climate Change.  The report focuses specifically on sea-level rise and coastal storms. The Phase I Strategy is a key component of the Maryland Climate Action Plan, detailing the actions necessary to protect Maryland's future economic well-being, environmental heritage and public safety in the face of climate change and sea level rise. This report lays out the specific priority policy recommendations of the ARWG to address short-and long-term adaptation and response measures, planning and policy integration, education and outreach, performance measurement, and, where necessary, new legislation and/or modifications to existing laws. Implementation of the Strategy is currently underway. The full Climate Action Plan (available on the Internet at http://www.mde.state.md.us/Air/climatechange).	f	f	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	t	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	 Completed Regional Or State Mid-Atlantic Marlyland Public Health and Safety Infrastructure Fresh Water Resources Transportation Built Coast (e.g., engineered solutions for shoreline protection) Managed Ecosystems Fisheries Natural Ecosystems Biota Social and Cultural Resources Economic Resources Sustainability of Marine Ecosystems Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) Improve Scientific Understanding of the Climate System and Essential Climate Variables Inform Mitigation and Adaptation Choices Promote Public Climate Literacy Translation of Climate Science for Sector/Decision-Maker Use  Plans, Assessments, Studies Adaptation/Action Plan	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	Comprehensive Strategy for Reducing Maryland’s Vulnerability to Climate Change Phase I: Sea-level rise and coastal storms	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	Maryland Commission on Climate Change Adaptation and Response Working Group	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	f	f	f	http://www.dnr.state.md.us/coastsmart/pdfs/comprehensive_strategy.pdf, http://www.mde.state.md.us/Air/climatechange	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
237	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	NH5	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	Derek Sowers, Piscataqua Region Estuary Partnership (Derek.sowers@unh.edu) 	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	An empirical relationship exists between storm tide, waves and coastal flooding or splash-over damage (NWS coastal flood study). Knowing this relationship will help predict when    flooding and splash-over events (such as beach erosion) might occur based on forecast water level (tide height) and wave height data. Working with the National Weather Service in Gray, Maine, NERACOOS and modelers in the Northeast region, a working prototype was developed using a water level model (NECOFS/FVCOM) and wave model (Wave Watch 3). This prototype is currently working for Hampton, New Hampshire and Scituate, Massachusetts locations. We hope to expand to other regions depending on need. For more information on how to read the nomogram, click here. This product could be used by emergency managers, coastal homeowners and other users with interest and concern about beach erosion from large-wave storms. During the Patriot's Day Storm, there were four high-tide cycles in which the water level was near or above flood stage and the waves were greater than 20' in height. This combination caused the tremendous amounts of coastal damage seen during the storm. The Coastal Flooding and Erosion Forecast System actually predicted days in advance of the Patriot's Day Storm that there was a high likelihood of this damage occurring. This capacity is extremely important to coastal property owners and emergency responders, resulting in dollars and lives saved. 	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	 Completed Regional Or State New England New Hampshire Public Health and Safety Emergency Management Infrastructure Climate Impacts on Water Resources Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) Inform Mitigation and Adaptation Choices Coastal and Oceanic Physical Forecasts and outlooks (monthly to annual, models)  Risk and Vulnerability	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	Coastal Flooding and Erosion Forecast\r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	f	f	f	f	f	Develop a working prototype that demonstrates the empirical relationship exists between storm tide, waves and coastal flooding or splash-over damage to help predict when    flooding and splash-over events (such as beach erosion) might occur.	f	f	f	f	f	Piscataqua Region Estuary Partnership (PREP)	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	\N	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	\N	f
205	f	f	t	t	t	t	f	t	t	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	MD6	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	Zoe Johnson, Maryland DNR, ZJohnson@dnr.md.state.us	f	t	f	f	Jan 2011	f	f	f	"The Maryland Commission on Climate Change released its Phase II Strategy for Reducing Maryland’s Vulnerability to Climate Change on January 24, 2011. The report outlines strategies to reduce the impacts of climate change, including sea level rise, increased temperature and changes in precipitation within the following sectors: Human Health; Agriculture; Forest and Terrestrial Ecosystems; Bay and Aquatic Environments; Water Resources; and Population Growth and Infrastructure. \r\n\r\nDeveloped in accordance with Governor O’Malley’s Executive Order, more than 80 experts collaborated and held several larger stakeholder meetings to create the Phase II Strategy. Along with its companion, the Phase I Strategy for Sea Level Rise and Coastal Storms (2008), the Phase II Strategy is a key component of Maryland’s Climate Action Plan. State agencies will use both strategies to guide and prioritize state-level activities with respect to both climate science and adaptation policy."\r\n	f	f	f	f	t	f	t	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	t	\N	t	f	f	t	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	t	f	f	f	 Completed Regional Or State Mid-Atlantic Marlyland Public Health and Safety Emergency Management Indirect Climate Hazards Vector-Borne Illness (e.g., West Nile Virus, Lymes disease) Heat Related Water Quality Infrastructure Fresh Water Resources Built Coast (e.g., engineered solutions for shoreline protection) Managed Ecosystems Fisheries Transportation Aquaculture Agriculture Forests Other Managed Ecosystems Natural Ecosystems Beaches Inland Habitats and Watersheds  Oceans Wetlands (e.g., saltwater, brackish, freshwater; tidal/non-tidal) Estuaries Coasts Biota Social and Cultural Resources Economic Resources Changes in Extremes of Weather and Climate Conservation/ Restoration of Sensitive Species and Habitats Climate Impacts on Water Resources Improve Scientific Understanding of the Climate System and Essential Climate Variables Inform Mitigation and Adaptation Choices Promote Public Climate Literacy Plans, Assessments, Studies Adaptation/Action Plan	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	Comprehensive Strategy for Reducing Maryland’s Vulnerability to Climate Change Phase II: Building societal economic and ecological resilience	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	t	f	f	f	Maryland Commission on Climate Change	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	http://www.dnr.state.md.us/climatechange/climatechange_phase2_adaptation_strategy.pdf	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	f	f	t	\N	f
1231	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	Natural Resources Council of Maine, nrcm@nrcm.org	f	f	f	f	2006	f	f	f	The Natural Resources Council of Maine (NRCM) released one of the most complete depictions ever done of the potential impacts on Maine’s coastline from rising sea levels due to global warming. Using the latest available science, NRCM’s analysis shows that coastal businesses, homes, wildlife habitat, transportation systems, and some of the state’s most treasured places are highly vulnerable to sea-level rise.\r\n\r\nNRCM calculated impacts for the entire coast, and selected several key areas to undertake detailed mapping using satellite images including, Portland, Kennebunkport, Old Orchard Beach, Scarborough, Bath, Georgetown, Mount Desert Island and the Cranberry Isles. We found at least 20 high risk cities and towns that stand to lose 20 to 30 percent of their land area, their municipal infrastructure, miles of highways, and millions of dollars of property.	f	f	f	t	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	 Completed Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) Regional Or State New England Maine Managed Ecosystems Infrastructure Natural Ecosystems Assess Climate and its Impacts Forecasts of Climate Impacts  Economic Impacts Vulnerability assessments (species, habitats and community vulnerability assessments) Economic Resources Plans, Assessments, Studies Impact Study Viewers and Web-based Tools Visualization tools (web-based, mapping programs)	f	f	f	f	t	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	he Effects of Sea-level Rise on Maine (web tool)	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	Natural Resources Council of Maine	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.nrcm.org/sea_level_rise.asp	f	f	t	f	t	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
208	f	f	t	f	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	MD9	t	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	t	f	f	Nov 2011	f	f	f	This Sea Level Rise Strategic Plan is the outcome of a study that Anne Arundel County and the Maryland Department of Natural Resources (DNR)  partnered on through the Coastal Communities Initiative Program to conduct a study of potential sea level rise impacts and develop adaptation strategies.  The project included four major components: 1) a vulnerability assessment to identify potential areas impacted by sea level rise and develop inventories of resources at risk; 2) development of a framework for interagency strategic planning; 3) development of a strategic plan; and 4) public outreach and education to promote public awareness of sea level rise issues. The Plan summarizes the State’s recent research and planning efforts related to sea level rise; discusses the key findings from the vulnerability assessment and other planning analysis; identifies the major planning issues for Anne Arundel County as related to sea level rise; and recommends future actions to protect resources and minimize impacts.	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	 Completed Regional Or State Mid-Atlantic Marlyland Local/City  Public Health and Safety Infrastructure Energy Communication and Commerce Fresh Water Resources Storm Water Wastewater Water Supply Transportation Built Coast (e.g., engineered solutions for shoreline protection) Managed Ecosystems Natural Ecosystems Social and Cultural Resources Economic Resources Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) Plans, Assessments, Studies Adaptation/Action Plan Risk and Vulnerability	f	f	t	f	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	Sea Level Rise Strategic Plan Anne Arundel County 	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	Anne Arundel County, Office of Planning and Zoning 	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	\N	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	http://www.dnr.state.md.us/CoastSmart/pdfs/AASLRStrategicPlan_final.pdf	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	t	f	f	\N	f
209	f	f	t	t	t	t	f	t	t	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	MD10	t	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	t	f	f	March 2008	f	f	f	This technical guidance outlines the impacts sea-level rise is projected to have in Dorchester county and provides a description of impacts to various sectors, including public health and safety, infrastructure, managed systems, and natural systems.  Four distinct planning strategies (Vulnerability and Impact Assessment; Long-Range and Comprehensive Planning; Codes, Regulations and Development Standards; and Public Education and Outreach) were outlined in the 2008 A Sea Level Response Strategy for the State of Maryland, and these same categories are addressed in this document. The guidance and discussion is provided to illustrate specific local implications of sea level rise. The author purposely wrote the guidance to focus on necessary changes at the local level. This guidance is presented in a manner intended to allow readers to understand how sea level rise may affect him or her in their daily lives, and to provide educators, planners, engineers, and elected officials a clear picture of the challenges facing them. \r\n	f	f	f	f	t	f	t	f	t	f	t	f	t	f	f	\N	t	f	f	t	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	t	f	f	f	 Completed Regional Or State Mid-Atlantic Marlyland Local/City  Public Health and Safety Emergency Management Indirect Climate Hazards Vector-Borne Illness (e.g., West Nile Virus, Lymes disease) Heat Related Water Quality Infrastructure Energy Communication and Commerce Fresh Water Resources Storm Water Wastewater Water Supply Transportation Built Coast (e.g., engineered solutions for shoreline protection) Managed Ecosystems Fisheries Aquaculture Agriculture Forests Other Managed Ecosystems Natural Ecosystems Coasts Estuaries Wetlands (e.g., saltwater, brackish, freshwater; tidal/non-tidal) Oceans Inland Habitats and Watersheds  Beaches Biota Social and Cultural Resources Economic Resources Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) Improve Scientific Understanding of the Climate System and Essential Climate Variables Inform Mitigation and Adaptation Choices Plans, Assessments, Studies Adaptation/Action Plan	f	f	t	f	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	Sea-Level Rise: Technical Guidance for Dorchester County  	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	t	f	f	f	Maryland Department of Natural Resources Coastal Zone Management Division 	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	http://www.dnr.state.md.us/dnrnews/pdfs/Dorchester.pdf	t	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	t	t	f	t	\N	f
210	f	f	t	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	MD11	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	Sept 2008	f	f	f	Somerset County obtained a grant from the Maryland Department of Natural Resources to assess the County’s vulnerability to sea level rise and to review and develop workable revisions to the County’s plans, development codes, and regulations to mitigate the identified impacts. The effects anticipated under various sea level rise scenarios include those associated with coastal storm flooding, both intensity and frequency, and those associated with more gradual changes in groundwater levels and  drainage.  The vulnerability assessment describes some of the associated problems that may occur, with particular emphasis on the effects related to coastal flooding.   The recommendations address suggested modifications to the County’s planning and regulatory mechanism, including the Floodplain Management Ordinance/Building Code, Zoning Ordinance, Subdivision Regulations, Comprehensive Plan, and Hazard Mitigation Plan.  	f	f	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	 Completed Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) Regional Or State Mid-Atlantic Marlyland Local/City  Public Health and Safety Infrastructure Managed Ecosystems Natural Ecosystems Economic Resources Changes in Extremes of Weather and Climate Improve Scientific Understanding of the Climate System and Essential Climate Variables Assess Climate and its Impacts Vulnerability assessments (species, habitats and community vulnerability assessments) Inform Mitigation and Adaptation Choices Maps (Imagery, geo-referenced data) Plans, Assessments, Studies Adaptation/Action Plan Management Guidance (i.e. structured decision making)	f	f	t	f	f	t	t	t	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	Somerset County, Maryland: Rising Sea Level Guidance	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	Somerset County	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.dnr.state.md.us/dnrnews/pdfs/SomersetSLRGuidance.pdf	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
213	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	MD14	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	Zoe Johnson, Maryland Department of Natural Resources, ZJohnson@dnr.state.md.us	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	The purpose of the policy is to provide direction and guidance to the Maryland Department of Natural Resources, which has the primary role within the state of managing natural resources and understanding vulnerability to climate change, on investments in and management of land aquisition, resources, and assets in the face of climate change.	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	 Completed Regional Or State Mid-Atlantic Marlyland Management Guidance (i.e. structured decision making)	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	Maryland Department of Natural Resources Policy: Building Resilience to Climate Change	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	Maryland Department of Natural Resources 	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.dnr.maryland.gov/dnrnews/pdfs/climate_change.pdf	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
214	f	f	t	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	MD15	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	Zoe Johnson, Maryland Department of Natural Resources, ZJohnson@dnr.state.md.us	f	f	f	f	October 2000	f	f	f	Sea level rise rates along Maryland's coastline are nearly twice those of the global average. Sea level has risen approximately one foot in the last century and is expected to rise another 2 - 3 feet by the year 2100. Sea level rise impacts coastal areas by exacerbating coastal flooding, influencing shoreline erosion, and submerging tidal wetlands and other low-lying lands. Such impacts pose a significant threat to the steep cliffs, wetlands and marshes, tidal estuaries, and sandy beaches, and barrier islands that comprise Maryland's coastal environment. Recognizing the need to begin planning for sea level rise, a NOAA Coastal Management Fellow with Maryland's Coastal Program developed a Sea Level Rise Response Strategy for the State of Maryland. The strategy sets forth the policy and implementation framework for reducing the State's overall vulnerability to sea level rise in the coming years.	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	 Completed Regional Or State Mid-Atlantic Marlyland Natural Ecosystems Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) Improve Scientific Understanding of the Climate System and Essential Climate Variables Assess Climate and its Impacts Vulnerability assessments (species, habitats and community vulnerability assessments) Inform Mitigation and Adaptation Choices Translate Climate Science for the Public  Promote Public Climate Literacy Hindcasts (climatologies, models) Forecasts and outlooks (monthly to annual, models)  Plans, Assessments, Studies Adaptation/Action Plan Adaptation/Action Plan Risk and Vulnerability Engagement Management Guidance (i.e. structured decision making) Regulatory/ Policy Guidance	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	A Sea Level Rise Response Strategy for the State of Maryland	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	Maryland Department of Natural Resources 	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	\N	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.dnr.state.md.us/bay/czm/sea_level_rise.html	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
211	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	MD12	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	\N	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	The purpose of the project was to develop new conservation criteria to identify coastal habitats that may help Maryland proactively adapt to sea level rise and increased storm events associated with climate change. Climate change targeting criteria resulting from this project will be used to review land acquisition projects, such as Coastal Estuarine and Land Conservation Program (CELCP), and will be added to the State’s current land conservation targeting program, “GreenPrint.” 	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	 Completed Regional Or State Mid-Atlantic Marlyland Natural Ecosystems Beaches Oceans Wetlands (e.g., saltwater, brackish, freshwater; tidal/non-tidal) Estuaries Coasts Conservation/ Restoration of Sensitive Species and Habitats Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) Assess Climate and its Impacts Downscale Climate Models Inform Mitigation and Adaptation Choices Translation of Climate Science for Sector/Decision-Maker Use  Physical Surface (Sea-surface temperature, sea level, salinity, ocean color, wave height) Coastal and Oceanic Projections (intra-annual to multi-decadal, including SLR and model down-scaling) Maps (Imagery, geo-referenced data) Viewers and Web-based Tools Visualization tools (web-based, mapping programs) Prioritization Tools	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	Coastal Land Conservation in Maryland:  Targeting Tools and Techniques for Sea Level Rise Adaptation and Response (Website and tools)	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	t	f	f	f	Maryland Department of Natural Resources, Chesapeake and Coastal Program	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	http://www.dnr.state.md.us/ccp/habitats_slr.asp	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	\N	f
243	f	f	t	f	f	t	f	f	t	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	VA3	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	Gwynn Crichton, Senior Conservation Program Manager, The Nature Conservancy, gcrichton@tnc.org \r\n	f	t	f	f	May 2011	f	f	f	The Nature Conservancy launched a climate change adaptation project for the\r\nEastern Shore of Virginia to more specifically characterize the current understanding of potential ecological effects due to climate change through\r\nan expert workshop, literature review and assessment of resource vulnerability using LiDAR (Light Detection and Ranging) data. In addition, the Conservancy, in\r\ncollaboration with partners and the local community, set out to use this understanding to inform the identification of strategic actions that would enhance resilience and facilitate adaptation of this globally important and productive coastal area upon which local communities and wildlife depend. To accomplish the latter, the Conservancy hosted the Eastern Shore Climate Change Adaptation Strategies Workshop in August 2010.  Out of the workshop, participants agreed on five primary adaptation strategies for the Eastern Shore and identified opportunities to implement these strategies.  This product describes the five adatpation strategies: local adaptation planning, shoreline management plans, restoration and protection of natural systems, groundwater management, and education and outreach.	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	 Completed Regional Or State Mid-Atlantic Virginia Public Health and Safety Water Quality Infrastructure Fresh Water Resources Water Supply Built Coast (e.g., engineered solutions for shoreline protection) Managed Ecosystems Natural Ecosystems Biota Social and Cultural Resources Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) Inform Mitigation and Adaptation Choices Translation of Climate Science for Sector/Decision-Maker Use  Evaluation of Climate Change Tools and Data Provision of Guidance Documents Promote Public Climate Literacy Translate Climate Science for the Public  Improve Communication and Education Tools  Adaptation/Action Plan Plans, Assessments, Studies	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	The Eastern Shore of Virginia: Strategies for Adapting to Climate Change	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	The Nature Conservancy Virginia	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	t	t	f	f	f	f	http://conserveonline.org/workspaces/e-shore-va-cc-adaptation/documents/the-eastern-shore-of-virginia-strategies-for-0/view.html\r\n	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	\N	f
1233	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	CO-OPS provides the national infrastructure, science, and technical expertise to monitor, assess, and distribute tide, current, water level, and other coastal oceanographic products and services that support NOAA's mission of environmental stewardship and environmental assessment and prediction. 241	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	VA1	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	E. Robert Thieler, U.S. Geological Survey, rthieler@usgs.gov	f	f	f	f	2004	f	f	f	Abstract: A coastal vulnerability index (CVI) was used to map relative vulnerability of the coast to future sea-level rise within Assateague Island National Seashore in \r\nMaryland and Virginia. The CVI ranks the following in terms of their physical \r\ncontribution to sea-level rise-related coastal change: geomorphology, regional coastal slope, rate of relative sea-level rise, shoreline change rates, mean tidal range and mean wave height. Rankings for each variable were combined and an index value calculated for 1-minute grid cells covering the park. The CVI highlights those regions where the physical effects of sea-level rise might be the greatest. This approach combines the coastal system's susceptibility to change with its natural ability to adapt to changing environmental conditions, yielding a quantitative, although relative, measure of the park's natural vulnerability to the effects of sea-level rise.  The CVI provides an objective technique for evaluation and long-term planning by scientists and park managers. Assateague Island consists of stable and washover dominated portions of barrier beach backed by wetland and marsh. The areas within Assateague that are likely to be most vulnerable to sea-level rise are those with the highest occurrence of overwash and the highest rates of shoreline change.	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	 Completed Regional Or State Mid-Atlantic Virginia Natural Ecosystems Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) Assess Climate and its Impacts Vulnerability assessments (species, habitats and community vulnerability assessments) Forecasts of Climate Conditions Forecasts of Climate Impacts  Translation of Climate Science for Sector/Decision-Maker Use  Inform Mitigation and Adaptation Choices Physical Coastal and Oceanic Surface (Sea-surface temperature, sea level, salinity, ocean color, wave height) Projections (intra-annual to multi-decadal, including SLR and model down-scaling) Maps (Imagery, geo-referenced data) Plans, Assessments, Studies Risk and Vulnerability	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	Coastal Vulnerability Assessment of Assateague Island National Seashore to Sea-Level Rise \r\n	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	U.S. Geological Survey\r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	\N	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/2004/1020/images/pdf/asis.pdf\r\n	f	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
246	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	VA6	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	Chris Burkett, Wildlife Action Plan Coordinator, Virginia Department of Game and Inland Fisheries, chris.burkett@dgif.virginia.gov	f	f	f	f	October 2009	f	f	f	This strategy was developed to provide initial guidance on actions Virginia’s conservation community can implement immediately to enhance the conservation of wildlife and habitats in the face of climate change while more comprehensive adaptation strategies are developed.  This effort to identify initial climate change adaptation strategies was initiated by the Virginia Department of Game and Inland Fisheries (DGIF), the National Wildlife Federation (NWF), and the Virginia Conservation Network (VCN).  This document is a compendium to Virginia’s Wildlife Action Plan, an existing document created to focus conservation efforts on preventing species from becoming endangered.  Strategies included in the document relate to coastal habitats. \r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	 Completed Regional Or State New England Mid-Atlantic Virginia Natural Ecosystems Biota Improve Scientific Understanding of the Climate System and Essential Climate Variables Conservation/ Restoration of Sensitive Species and Habitats Inform Mitigation and Adaptation Choices Plans, Assessments, Studies Other	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	Conserving Virginia’s Fish and Wildlife for the Future:  Preparing for a Changing\r\nClimate	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	Virginia Department of Game and Inland Fisheries, National Wildlife Federation, and Virginia Conservation Network	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.bewildvirginia.org/climate-change/	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
1119	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	t	f	f	September 2011	f	f	f	From the Executive Summary:  NOAA has focused its efforts on four climate-related challenges to society. These \r\nchallenges represent a spectrum of local and national needs for which NOAA can \r\ndevelop and deliver services, and provide information, that can help inform effective \r\nadaptation actions and other climate-sensitive decisions. The four societal challenges, as \r\ndefined in “A Climate Service in NOAA: Connecting Climate Science to Decision \r\nMaking – Vision and Strategic Framework,” are\r\n\r\n1. Climate Impacts on Water Resources\r\nProviding coordinated and authoritative information systems to guide water \r\nresource managers.\r\n2. Coasts and Climate Resilience\r\nUnderstanding physical processes driving sea-level rise and coastal inundation, \r\nand providing best available information to decision makers on sea-level change \r\nimpacts and adaptive management strategies.\r\n3. Sustainability of Marine Ecosystems\r\nImproving understanding of, and information about, the impacts of climate on \r\nocean physical, chemical, and biological properties critical to managing large \r\nmarine ecosystems.\r\n4. Changes in Extremes of Weather and Climate\r\nDeveloping and delivering information to prepare for and adapt to climate and \r\nweather extremes, including droughts, floods, heat waves, and cold snaps.\r\nThis needs assessment will focus on challenge 2 on the resilience of coasts to the impacts \r\nof sea-level change. The term sea-level change acknowledges that while global or \r\neustatic sea levels are rising, local levels, or relative sea levels in certain places, may be  rising or falling.\r\n\r\nThe results of the literature review on the challenge of coastal sea-level change, presented in this document, represent a snapshot of gaps in data, information, and services as captured in 55 documents, presentations, and publications. This synthesis of findings highlights the needs of coastal decision makers for resources that can assist them in making informed decisions about the risks and impacts of sea-level change. The results of this report are intended to provide NOAA with current information on the needs of coastal decision makers in order to guide its development of trainings, engagement efforts, decision-support tools, and applications.	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	 National Natural Ecosystems Social and Cultural Resources Other Training and Capacity Building	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	Coastal Sea-Level Change Societal Challenge Needs Assessment Report	t	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	NOAA Sea Grant	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.floods.org/ace-files/documentlibrary/committees/Coastal/NOAA_Coastal_Sea_Level_Change_Societal_Challenge_Needs_Assessment_Report.pdf	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
249	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	VA9	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	Dr. Oswald Schmitz, Oastler Professor of Population and Community Ecology\r\n	f	f	f	f	Winter 2013	f	f	f	Recognizing a need for clarity within this field, the Yale School of Forestry & Environmental Studies convened a working group of the nation’s leading conservation biologists, modelers, and policymakers to develop guidance for integrating climate-change adaptation strategies into the context of natural-resource planning and policymaking.   The product of this working group—The Yale Framework—assists conservation planners in selecting the assessment and modeling strategies that are most relevant to their specific needs. Rather than supplanting existing techniques, the Yale Framework provides simplified and flexible advice on models and data, and presents a list of commonly used datasets that can be helpful to planners. The Framework also provides a structured menu of options that assist resource managers in determining the best possible approach to conservation, as opposed to offering a prescriptive approach to natural resource management. The Yale Mapping Framework has been built using the Data Basin platform. Data Basin makes it simple to find reliable data and make compelling visualizations. Planners can locate datasets, combine multiple layers together in a visualization session, and then share maps with their colleagues. With the Data Basin data and tools, planners have everything they need to make their assessments.\r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	 Ongoing National Natural Ecosystems Biota Conservation/ Restoration of Sensitive Species and Habitats Inform Mitigation and Adaptation Choices Translation of Climate Science for Sector/Decision-Maker Use  Evaluation of Climate Change Tools and Data Training and Capacity Building Data Support tools (help using specific data products) Adaptation and Mitigation Guidance, including Best Practices Manuals, Toolkits, and Guides Viewers and Web-based Tools Monitoring tools (e.g. U.S. Drought Monitor) Visualization tools (web-based, mapping programs) Prioritization Tools Management Guidance (i.e. structured decision making)	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	t	The Yale Mapping Framework for Integrating Climate Adaptatin and Landscape Conservation Planning\r\n	t	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	t	f	Yale University, School of Forestry & Environmental Studies\r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	f	t	f	f	f	f	http://www.databasin.org/yale\r\n	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
491	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	S8	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	This document describes the mapping process used by the NOAA Coastal Services Center to map potential impacts to marsh environments due to sea level rise for the Sea Level Rise and Coastal Flooding Impacts viewer. Generally, this process can be described as a modified bathtub approach that attempts to account for local/regional tidal variability.	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	 Completed National Risk and Vulnerability Training and Capacity Building Natural Ecosystems Estuaries Wetlands (e.g., saltwater, brackish, freshwater; tidal/non-tidal)	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	Detailed Methodology for Mapping Sea-Level Rise Marsh igration	t	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	NOAA, Coastal Services Center	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.csc.noaa.gov/slr/viewer/assets/pdfs/Marsh_Migration_Methods.pdf	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	\N	f
1234	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	f	\N	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	NCDDC@noaa.gov, 866.732.2382	f	f	f	f	\N	t	f	f	NOAA's National Coastal Data Development Center (NCDDC) produces the NOAA Extreme Weather Information Sheets (NEWIS). Published each year for the Atlantic hurricane season, the NOAA Extreme Weather Information Sheets provide critical information for contacting government officials and monitoring information resources. The laminated and waterproof NOAA Extreme Weather Information Sheets are an ideal reference in the home, automobile, or boat. NOAA Extreme Weather Information Sheets provide residents with a "one-stop" ready reference containing phone numbers and Web site information residents can use during potentially life-threatening weather emergencies.	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	f	t	f	f	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	 Changes in Extremes of Weather and Climate National Public Health and Safety Emergency Management Economic Resources Climate Society Interactions Communication and Education Decision Making Physical Atmospheric Coastal and Oceanic Engagement	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	NOAA Extreme Weather Information Sheets	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	NOAA National Coastal Climate Data Development Center	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.ncddc.noaa.gov/activities/weather-ready-nation/newis/	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
292	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	CT2	f	f	t	f	f	f	t	t	\N	f	t	f	f	July 2005	f	f	f	Executive Summary: "In accordance with Section 7 of Public Act No. 08-98, An Act Concerning Connecticut Global Warming Solutions, the Governor‘s Steering Committee (GSC) on Climate Change established an Adaptation Subcommittee.  The GSC charged the Adaptation Subcommittee with evaluating, ―the projected impact of climate change in the state on: (1) Infrastructure, including, but not limited to, buildings, roads, railroads, airports, dams, reservoirs, and sewage treatment and water filtration facilities; (2) natural resources and ecological habitats, including, but not limited to, coastal and inland wetlands, forests and rivers; (3) public health; and (4) agriculture.‖  This assessment effort is to be followed by a report due in mid-2010 that also contains the results of the above impacts assessment and, …recommendations for changes to existing state and municipal programs, laws or regulations to enable municipalities and natural habitats to adapt to harmful climate change impacts and to mitigate such impacts."‖\r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	 Completed Regional Or State New England Connecticut Infrastructure Managed Ecosystems Natural Ecosystems Biota Social and Cultural Resources Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) Climate Impacts on Water Resources Changes in Extremes of Weather and Climate Conservation/ Restoration of Sensitive Species and Habitats Assess Climate and its Impacts Inform Mitigation and Adaptation Choices Other	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	The Impacts of Climate Change on Connecticut Agriculture, Infrastructure, Natural Resources and Public Health: A Report by the Adaptation Subcommittee to the Governor’s Steering  Committee on Climate Change\r\n	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	Governor's Steering Committee on Climate Change, Adaptation Subcommittee\r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://ctclimatechange.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/Impacts-of-Climate-Change-on-CT-Ag-Infr-Nat-Res-and-Pub-Health-April-2010.pdf\r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	\N	f
293	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	CT1	f	f	t	f	f	f	t	t	\N	f	t	f	f	March 2009	f	f	f	The Connecticut Department of Environment Protection has developed a series of initial climate adaptation fact sheets, Facing Our Future, that detail current observations and provide some cursory recommendations for alternative approaches to foster adaptation at the local and regional level. 291	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	CT3	f	f	t	f	f	t	t	f	\N	f	t	f	f	\N	f	f	f	The Connecticut Coastal Hazards Viewer is an online mapping tool designed to allow users access to several pertinent suites of data for coastal Connecticut. Presented here are data representing sea level rise, high-resolution coastal elevation, hurricane storm surge, coastal erosion, and environmental observations such as tides, water quality, waves and currents. The tool includes: sea level rise visualization data for coastal areas on Long Island Sound, Coastal Digital Elevation model using bare earth LiDAR data for all of Connecticuts shoreline, hurricane surge inundation data, erosion susceptibility data, and LIS Environmental Observations Data.  \r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	 Completed Regional Or State New England Connecticut Infrastructure Managed Ecosystems Natural Ecosystems Biota Social and Cultural Resources Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) Improve Scientific Understanding of the Climate System and Essential Climate Variables Assess Climate and its Impacts Forecasts of Climate Conditions Inform Mitigation and Adaptation Choices Maps (Imagery, geo-referenced data) Projections (intra-annual to multi-decadal, including SLR and model down-scaling) Viewers and Web-based Tools Changes in Extremes of Weather and Climate Visualization tools (web-based, mapping programs)	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	Connecticut Coastal Hazards Viewer	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	Department of Energy and Environmental Protection\r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.ct.gov/dep/cwp/view.asp?a=2705&q=480782&depNav_GID=2022\r\n	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
295	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	ME2	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	Kristen Grant, Marine Extension Associate, Maine Sea Grant,  207.646.1555 x115, kngrant@maine.edu\r\n	f	f	f	f	2010	f	f	f	The Maine Sea Grant College Program, in partnership with the Oregon Sea Grant College Program,  conducted a two-year NOAA-funded project: 1) to study how climate variability and coastal hazards may be affecting Maine and Oregon's coastal regions and how these impacts relate to coastal development in the two states; 2) to encourage and facilitate collaboration among and between decision makers and coastal property owners to determine and implement appropriate responses to climate variability on short and longer timescales; 3) to discover the barriers that targeted groups in the states have to taking action to prepare for or mitigate the effects of climate change; and 4) to develop educational and informational materials and strategies concerning n these topics. The ultimate goal of the project is to have definitive actions that result in coastal communities being more resilient to climate variability. In Maine this included a survey and focus groups of property owners, municipal officials, and recreationists to determine "barriers and benefits that coastal property owners and municipal officials face in taking action to prepare for impacts from coastal storms, flooding, and erosion." This report summarizes the results of this project and the surveys and focus groups.  The project also resulted in a documentary and a website. \r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	 Completed Regional Or State New England Maine Infrastructure Natural Ecosystems Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) Promote Public Climate Literacy Improve Communication and Education Tools  Other, report Engagement Public Engagement Education Public Education	f	t	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	Climate Variability and Coastal Community Resilience: Testing a National Model of State-based Outreach\r\n	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	Maine Sea Grant\r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.seagrant.umaine.edu/files/pdf-global/10SARPtech_final.pdf/ http://www.seagrant.umaine.edu/extension/coastal-community-resilience\r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
1238	f	f	t	f	f	t	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	\N	f	f	f	f	September 2010	f	f	f	From the Executive Overview: The Strategic Plan’s primary purposes \r\nare to (1) lay out our vision for \r\naccomplishing our mission to “work \r\nwith others to conserve, protect, and \r\nenhance fish, wildlife, and plants \r\nand their habitats for the continuing \r\nbenefit of the American people” in the \r\nface of accelerating climate change; \r\nand (2) provide direction for our own \r\norganization and its employees, \r\ndefining our role within the context \r\nof the Department of the Interior and \r\nthe larger conservation community. In \r\nthis plan, we express our commitment \r\nto our vision through strategic goals \r\nand objectives that we believe must be accomplished to sustain fish and wildlife nationally and internationally.  In an appended 5-year action Plan for Implementing the Climate Change Strategic Plan, we identify specific actions that will lead to the accomplishment of our goals and objectives.	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	 Completed Conservation/ Restoration of Sensitive Species and Habitats National Changes in Extremes of Weather and Climate Biota Natural Ecosystems Inform Mitigation and Adaptation Choices Plans, Assessments, Studies Adaptation/Action Plan U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	Rising to the Urgent Challenge Strategic Plan for Responding to Accelerating Climate Change	t	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.fws.gov/home/climatechange/pdf/CCStrategicPlan.pdf	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
301	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	ME8	f	f	t	f	f	t	f	f	Peter A. Slovinsky, Coastal Geologist, Stephen M. Dickson, Marine Geologist\r\n	f	f	f	f	Sept 2009	f	f	t	"For this project, the Maine Geological Society (MGS) simulated the impacts of sea level rise on tidal inundation levels, and also used tidal elevations as proxies for existing coastal wetland boundaries.   These tidal elevations were calculated by MGS using NOAA NOS Tide Charts (NOS, 2009a), and benchmark data sheets for Portland, Maine (NOS, 2009b).  LIDAR raster data was \r\nused to create simulations of both existing marsh conditions, and potential future \r\nmarsh conditions after sea level rise.   Analysis was done for Cousins River, Yarmouth; BAck Cove, Portland; and Thomas Bay, Brunswick. 298	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	ME5	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	Sam Merrill, smerrill@usm.maine.edu (207) 228-8596\r\n	f	t	f	f	\N	f	f	f	In Portland, Maine and Hampton/Seabrook New Hampshire, climate change adaptation processes are underway. In both locations COAST (COastal Adaptation to Sea level rise Tool) is being used to enhance these efforts.   The Environmental Finance Center conducted a study using their COAST tool, which helps communities evaluate costs and benefits of adaptation actions municipalities might undertake in response to threats of sea level rise and storm surge over the next century. The study evaluated potential lost real estate values in the Bayside portion of Portland, under different sea level rise, storm surge, and adaptation scenarios.   Through 3D visualizations, tallies of expected damages, and a presentation describing these results, the EFC is encouraging interested stakeholders in Portland to become involved in a larger, upcoming adaptation planning process for the city. \r\n	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	 Completed Regional Or State New England Maine Infrastructure Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) Changes in Extremes of Weather and Climate Assess Climate and its Impacts Vulnerability assessments (species, habitats and community vulnerability assessments) Risk Assessments Inform Mitigation and Adaptation Choices Projections (intra-annual to multi-decadal, including SLR and model down-scaling) Vulnerability Assessment Plans, Assessments, Studies Ongoing New Hampshire Public Health and Safety Social and Cultural Resources Economic Resources Maps (Imagery, geo-referenced data) Engagement Viewers and Web-based Tools Training and Capacity Building	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	Sea Level Rise and Storm Surge Adaptation Analysis via COAST (COastal Adaptation to Sea level rise Tool))\r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	t	f	New England Environmental Finance Center (EFC) at the Muskie School of Public Service, University of Southern Maine\r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	\N	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://efc.muskie.usm.maine.edu/pages/projects_cre.html\r\n	f	f	t	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
1242	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	(303) 497-8139 , narccap@ucar.edu  	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	The North American Regional Climate Change Assessment Program (NARCCAP) is an international program to produce high resolution climate change simulations in order to investigate uncertainties in regional scale projections of future climate and generate climate change scenarios for use in impacts research.  NARCCAP modelers are running a set of regional climate models (RCMs) driven by a set of atmosphere-ocean general circulation models (AOGCMs) over a domain covering the conterminous United States and most of Canada.  Registration as a NARCCAP user is required in order to access data.	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	 Ongoing International Canada National Improve Scientific Understanding of the Climate System and Essential Climate Variables Physical Atmospheric Forecasts and outlooks (monthly to annual, models)  	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	North American Regional Climate Change Assessment Program (NARCCAP)	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	t	f	The Nationals Science Foundation (NSF), Department of Energy (DOE), the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), and the Canadian consortium OURANOS are providing initial funding for the program.	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
1243	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	(303) 497-8139 , narccap@ucar.edu  	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	The North American Regional Climate Change Assessment Program (NARCCAP) is an international program to produce high resolution climate change simulations in order to investigate uncertainties in regional scale projections of future climate and generate climate change scenarios for use in impacts research.  NARCCAP modelers are running a set of regional climate models (RCMs) driven by a set of atmosphere-ocean general circulation models (AOGCMs) over a domain covering the conterminous United States and most of Canada.  Registration as a NARCCAP user is required in order to access data.	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	 Ongoing International Canada National Improve Scientific Understanding of the Climate System and Essential Climate Variables Physical Atmospheric Forecasts and outlooks (monthly to annual, models)  	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	North American Regional Climate Change Assessment Program (NARCCAP)	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	t	f	NSF, DOE, NOAA, and the Canadian consortium OURANOS are providing initial funding	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
299	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	ME6	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	December 2009	f	f	f	From the report: This report describes how the climate of Casco Bay watershed in Maine has changed over the past century and how the future climate of the region is likely to be affected by climate change.  To generate future projections for Portland, Farmington, and Lewiston, simulated temperature and precipitation from four climate models were fitted to local, long-term weather observations.  Two future scenarios were used for estimated carbon emissions. For the  lower emissions scenario, conservation practices and development of renewable energy reduce emissions below those of today by 2100. In the higher \r\nemissions scenario, fossil fuels are assumed to remain a primary energy resource, and emissions grow four times the amount of today by 2100.  The scenarios describe climate in terms of temperature and precipitation for three future periods: the  near-term, 2010-2039, mid-century, 2040-2069, and end-of-century, 2070-2099. All changes are relative to a historical baseline, 1970-1999. 304	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	ME11	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	t	f	f	October 2012	f	f	f	From the website: The Buzzards Bay NEP has updated our landmark 1991 Buzzards Bay Comprehensive Conservation and Management Plan (CCMP), to reflect the progress achieved since that plan was finalized, the many tasks still not completed, as well as new challenges. The updated plan includes new, updated, and reaffirmed goals, objectives, and management solutions to meet the environmental needs for Buzzards Bay and its surrounding watershed into the next decade. The original plan was approved by EPA in 1992.\r\n\r\nThe updated Buzzards Bay watershed management plan is meant to be a blueprint to continue to help guide municipalities and watershed partners in their ongoing efforts to protect and restore water quality and living resources in the bay and surrounding watershed. We believe the update of the Buzzards Bay CCMP is also an excellent opportunity for municipalities to advance local priorities, and to request new measures or support from the state and federal government. While the Buzzards Bay watershed plan is not a regulatory document, the contents of the updated plan will help guide state and federal grants, technical assistance, and policy changes that will affect Buzzards Bay communities for years to come. For these reasons, the review of the new plan warrants the attention of local officials and the public.	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	 Completed Regional Or State New England Massachusetts Public Health and Safety Infrastructure Managed Ecosystems Natural Ecosystems Social and Cultural Resources Economic Resources Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) Changes in Extremes of Weather and Climate Inform Mitigation and Adaptation Choices Plans, Assessments, Studies Completed	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	Buzzards Bay Comprehensive Conservation and Management Plan (CCMP)\r\n	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	Buzzards Bay National Estuary Program\r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.buzzardsbay.org/newccmp-shorelines.htm\r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
308	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	RI3	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	Using Google Earth, this tool allows the user to view an overlay of 5 feet of sea-level rise in Rhode Island.
