310	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	RI5	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	Spring 2011	f	f	t	Detailed elevation data were collected with airborne LiDAR technology for the entire area of Rhode Island between April 22 and May 6, 2011. Rhode Island's data collection was a component of the larger Northeast LiDAR Project. Basic specifications for the data acquisition:\r\n1) 1 meter nominal pulse spacing\r\n2) National Spatial Standard for Spatial Data Accuracy (NSSDA) Fundamental Vertical Accuracy (FVA) 29.4cm @ 95% confidence, based on 15cm RMSEz in open terrain land cover.\r\n3) Horizontal coordinate system: NAD83 UTM Zone 19 North, meters\r\n4) Vertical reference: NAVD88 (GEOID99), meters\r\n5) No tidal coordination\r\n6) Meet or exceed standards defined in version 12 of the USGS National Geospatial Program Base Lidar Specification (PDF).\r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	 Completed Depth and Elevation Data	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	Rhode Island LiDAR \r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.edc.uri.edu/rigis/data/download/lidar/2011USGS/\r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
305	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	ME12	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	Don Cameron, Maine Natural Areas Program, 207-287-8041; Don.S.Cameron@maine.gov\r\n	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	From Project Document: The Maine Natural Areas Program and the Maine Geological Service have been working on an SLR simulation.  The objective of the project is to identify areas of the landscape where tidal marshes can migrate or expand under several SLR scenarios, and to provide that information to relevant public and private planning and conservation organizations.  Thus far the project is only addressing south coastal Maine, as that is the portion of the coast for which LiDAR data was available when we started.  We will eventually expand the project coast wide as LiDAR for the remainder of the coast has recently become available.  Our SLR simulation is a simple bathtub model and does not attempt to address any of the dynamic processes affecting the development of tidal marshes.  At this point we are not attempting to predict where marshes might be lost or where whole new systems might form, rather just where existing marshes might migrate or expand to.\r\n\r\nSteps in the project completed to date:\r\n\r\n- all tidal marshes greater than 5 acres excluding isolated fringing marsh have been mapped in GIS using ortho photography\r\n- ground truthing of LiDAR accuracy in and adjacent to marshes was completed across the range of the project\r\n- ground truthing of vegetation was completed in a subset of remotely mapped marshes across the range of the project\r\n- GIS simulations for 1 meter and 0.6 meters highest annual tide (HAT) of SLR that identify undeveloped areas of the landscape where existing marshes might migrate or expand to have also been completed (see attached map for sample of results).\r\n\r\nSteps remaining include analysis of the results, formatting the data for external use, and sharing the data with potential users.\r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	 Ongoing Regional Or State New England Maine Natural Ecosystems Wetlands (e.g., saltwater, brackish, freshwater; tidal/non-tidal) Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) Assess Climate and its Impacts Vulnerability assessments (species, habitats and community vulnerability assessments) Forecasts of Climate Conditions Inform Mitigation and Adaptation Choices Projections (intra-annual to multi-decadal, including SLR and model down-scaling) Maps (Imagery, geo-referenced data)	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	Maine Sea-Level Rise Simulation	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	t	f	Maine Natural Areas Program and Maine Geological Service	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	t	\N	f
1244	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	t	f	\N	f	f	f	NCDC is the world's largest active archive of weather data. Our mission is to provide access and stewardship to National resource of global climate and weather related data and information, and assess and monitor climate variation and change. This effort requires the acquisition, quality control, processing, summarization, dissemination, and preservation of a vast array of climatological data generated by the national and international meteorological services. The NCDC mission is global in nature and provides the U.S. climate representative to the World Meteorological Organization, the World Data Center System, and other international scientific programs. NCDC also operates the World Data Center for Meteorology, Asheville.	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	 National Regional Or State New England Mid-Atlantic Central Great Lakes South East Changes in Extremes of Weather and Climate Improve Scientific Understanding of the Climate System and Essential Climate Variables Physical In situ Observations Satellite Remote Observations Observing Systems Data Stewardship and Provisions	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	NOAA National Climatic Data Center	t	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	t	f	f	f	f	NOAA 	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	\N	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
313	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	RI8	f	f	t	f	f	t	f	f	Pam Rubinoff, URI Coastal Resources Center/ RI Sea Grant, rubi@crc.uri.edu	f	f	f	f	May 2011	f	f	t	The Rhode Island Sea Grant College Program (RISG) program worked with partners from the Rhode Island Coastal Resources Management Council (CRMC), the Statewide Planning Program, The Nature Conservancy (TNC), the Rhode Island Emergency Management Agency (RIEMA), the University of Rhode Island Environmental Data Center (URI-EDC), and other institutions,  to advance issues related to understanding climate change impacts related to sea level rise, flooding and erosion, and the associated economic, social and environmental implications for the state's 21 coastal communities.  Much has been done related to these issues in terms of science synthesis, policy development, and outreach.  From this work, the need for a more detailed analysis of vulnerable assets, adaptation strategies and implementation techniques that can be applied in Rhode Island’s coastal communities was identified.  The key obstacle has been the lack of digital elevation data for coastal Rhode Island and the lack of availability of this information.   This project collected and synthesized the best available digital elevation data for coastal Rhode Island as of 2010, resulting in a series of map and data products that resource managers and decision makers can use to assess vulnerability to projected sea level rise. The high resolution topography and bathymetry data can be used for many other applications as well. This collaborative project included a participatory process to ensure that the products are suited for state and municipal agencies and resource managers in the state. In addition to statewide products, a pilot project was implemented with the Town of North Kingstown to demonstrate the use of these tools for local planning and action to address sea level rise and increased inundation expected in the future.  \r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	 Completed Regional Or State New England Rhode Island Infrastructure Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) Assess Climate and its Impacts Risk Assessments Forecasts of Climate Conditions Social Impacts (Health and Public Security) Forecasts and outlooks (monthly to annual, models)  Physical Coastal and Oceanic Surface (Sea-surface temperature, sea level, salinity, ocean color, wave height) Depth and Elevation Data Risk and Vulnerability	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	Mapping Assets Vulnerable to Sea Level Rise North Kingstown, Rhode Island\r\n\r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	Rhode Island Sea Grant College Program; University of Rhode Island Environmental Data Center\r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	\N	t	t	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://seagrant.gso.uri.edu/z_downloads/coast/coast_lidar_method.pdf \r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
312	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	RI7	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	The  Narragansett Bay National Estuartine Research Reserve has been monitoring salt marsh structural parameters for 10 years.  More recently, the Reserve entered into a 3‐year project with 4 additional reserves to conduct coordinated salt marsh monitoring at a national scale. This marsh monitoring component will set up Reserve marshes as long‐term reference sites that can be used to 1) evaluate how natural salt marshes are changing over time in response to the large‐scale effects of global climate change and sea‐level rise, and 2) evaluate the ecological changes at restoring marshes around Narragansett Bay as they recover from tidal restrictions. This program will enable scientists and managers to assess how these marshes are changing over time in response to climate change, restoration, and other natural and anthropogenic stressors.  \r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	 Ongoing Regional Or State New England Rhode Island Natural Ecosystems Wetlands (e.g., saltwater, brackish, freshwater; tidal/non-tidal) Assess Climate and its Impacts Experimental Impacts (single species and multi-species, physiology and ecology, monitoring	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	Narragansett Bay Research Reserve Sentiental Marsh Monitoring\r\n	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	t	f	Narragansett Bay National Estuartine Research Reserve\r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	\N	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.nbnerr.org/Content/NBNERR_Monitoring_Plan_2011.pdf\r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	\N	f
314	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	RI9	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	Kevin Ruddock \r\n	f	f	f	f	Oct 2011	f	f	f	From the Introduction: These map atlases and Geographic Information System (GIS) data are the result of a modeling exercise to show the most likely locations of future salt (tidal) march habitat given a one, three and five foot sea level rise (SLR.) The Sea Level Affecting Marshes Model (SLAMM) was used with the most current wetland and elevation data to produce these projections. The modeling for this project was done using the Sea Level \r\nAffecting Marsh Model (SLAMM) version 6.0.1. Model input data were processed with ESRI ArcMap 10 GIS software. ArcMap was also used to combine and display the model \r\noutputs.\r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	 Completed Regional Or State New England Rhode Island Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) Conservation/ Restoration of Sensitive Species and Habitats Maps (Imagery, geo-referenced data)	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	Using SLAMM 6.0.1 to Model Likely Paths for Salt Marsh Migration in North Kingstown, Rhode Island in Response to Sea Level Rise\r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	The Nature Conservancy Rhode Island\r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	\N	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://seagrant.gso.uri.edu/z_downloads/coast/tools_NK_SLAMM_methods_small.pdf\r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
1259	f	f	t	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	Nova Scotia Department of Environment, climatechange@gov.ns.ca 	f	f	f	f	January 2009	f	f	f	Nova Scotia’s Climate Change Action Plan has two main goals: reducing our \r\ncontribution to climate change by reducing our greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions \r\nand preparing for changes to our climate that are already inevitable. 1260	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	August 2003	f	f	f	From the Introduction: This report is an economic analysis of a pilot impact assessment performed in three lowlying Maryland communities: Shadyside in Anne Arundel County; Piney Point and St. George’s \r\nIsland in St. Mary’s County; and Upper and Middle Hooper Islands in Dorchester County. 201	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	MD2	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	Kate Skaggs, Maryland Coast Smart, kskaggs@dnr.state.md.us 	f	t	f	f	\N	f	f	f	Through Maryland’s CoastSmart Communities Initiative, the Chesapeake and Coastal Program is helping local communities identify and implement strategies to protect life and property vulnerable to coastal hazards and climate change. From hands-on training and planning tools to financial resources, the Chesapeake & Coastal Program is ensuring that local communities have the tools that they need to identify and take the necessary actions to become ready, adaptive and resilient to the impacts of climate change.  In partnership with the National  Ocean and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), the Chesapeake & Coastal Program provides financial assistance to local communities for coastal hazards and sea-level rise response planning. Funding has been used to assist local communities invest in computer models, implement land use plans and establish development codes and ordinances. The Chesapeake & Coastal Program develops and provides technical tools and skill-building opportunities to local communities on how to implement climate change and sea level rise measures into local policies and programs.	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	Ongoing Regional Or State Mid-Atlantic Marlyland Public Health and Safety Infrastructure Managed Ecosystems Other Sector  Social and Cultural Resources Economic Resources Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) Inform Mitigation and Adaptation Choices Promote Public Climate Literacy Evaluation of Climate Change Tools and Data Collaborative Stakeholder Engagements Provision of Guidance Documents Engagement Education Training and Capacity Building Viewers and Web-based Tools Stakeholder Engagement Visualization tools (web-based, mapping programs)	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	Maryland Coast Smart	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	Help local communities to identify and implement strategies to project people and property from coastal hazards and climate change.	f	f	f	t	f	Maryland Department of Natural Resources Chesapeake and Coastal Program	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://maryland.coastsmart.org/; http://www.dnr.state.md.us/CoastSmart/	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
318	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	NJ2	f	f	t	f	f	t	f	f	Rick Lathrop, Director, Center for Remote Sensing and Spatial Analysis (CRSSA), lathrop@crssa.rutgers.edu	f	f	f	f	2007	f	f	f	This report is provides details on the geographic information system-based approach used to identify vulnerable development and where this development is constricting the natural dynamics of coastline migration. This study was part of a broader assessment of New Jersey’s coastal environmental resources conducted by the Walton Center for Remote Sensing & Spatial Analysis (CRSSA) of Rutgers University and the American Littoral Society.  This report expands on Cooper et al., 2005.  "The primary objectives of this work is to examine six specific issues related to coastal vulnerability and future adaptability: to map near shore development; to map the land use/land cover that is vulnerable to tidal surge inundation and flooding; to map the distance from coastal waters to the first developed obstruction (i.e. how far removed is existing development from the surging coastal waters); to map the degree of shoreline alteration due to coastal protection structures; to map where coastal beach and dune habitats are relatively undisturbed; and delineate those portions of our coastal wetland complex that are free to retreat inland as part of the natural landward migration process (i.e., where are coastal wetlands bordered by undeveloped vs. developed uplands). 319	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	NJ3	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	\N	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	The project is a collaboration between the Jacques Cousteau National Estuarine Research Reserve (JC NERR) and Rutgers University Center for Remote Sensing & Spatial Analysis (CRSSA).  CRSSA is responsible for the technical aspects, while JC NERR is responsible for the collaborative, evaluation/assessment and knowledge dissemination portions of the project.  In summary, the proposed project has three main outcomes: 1) serve as a demonstration project as to the feasibility and utility of enhanced GIS/LiDAR-based assessment of coastal infrastructure and habitat vulnerability to sea level rise; and 2) develop a suite internet-accessible geospatial and database visualization and analysis tools that will facilitate the dissemination of this information; and 3) promote enhanced preparedness and land use planning decisions in the face of continued sea level rise. The first step in this project is to conduct a needs assessment of our intended users to (1) identify their current level and source of information regarding sea level rise and climate change impacts to New Jersey’s bay and ocean front , (2) identify parameters that are most important to their decision-making (http://www.jcnerr.org/Needs%20Assessment%20Final%20report.pdf), (3) determine their level of comfort with online mapping and decision support tools (http://www.jcnerr.org/Usability%20Testing.final%20report.pdf), (4) determine the best structure for querying and interacting with the CV10 DSS, (5) determine what would enable or prevent them from using such a product. \r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	 Ongoing Regional Or State 323	f	f	t	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	NJ7	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	Martha Sullivan Sapp, New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection, Martha.Sapp@dep.state.nj.us\r\n	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	This program is designed "to achieve, in partnership with others, a system of interconnected open spaces, whose protection will preserve and enhance New Jersey's natural environment and its historic, scenic, and recreational resources for public use and enjoyment."  A new aspect of the program is the Blue Acres program where properties (including structures) that have been damaged by, or may be prone to incurring damage caused by, storms or storm-related flooding, or that may buffer or protect other lands from such damage, are eligible for acquisition.\r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	 Regional Or State Mid-Atlantic New Jersey Managed Ecosystems Natural Ecosystems Conservation/ Restoration of Sensitive Species and Habitats Plans, Assessments, Studies Adaptation/Action Plan	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	New Jersey's Green Acres and Blue Acres Program\r\n	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection\r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.nj.gov/dep/greenacres/\r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
320	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	NJ4	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	Dorina Frizzera, NJ DEP, dorina.frizzera@dep.state.nj.us	f	t	f	f	\N	f	f	f	The report focuses on two tools: the Coastal Community Vulnerability Assessment Protocol  (CCVAP) and a resilience assessment.  THe CCVAP  is a GIS-based tool that was developed to help land use planners, hazard mitigation planners, emergency managers, and other local decision-makers to identify vulnerability to coastal hazards and sea-level rise at the community level.   The CCVAP oultines the needed steps to identify  vulnerable land areas under present and future inundation scenarios geospatially.  Using these inundation scenarios (0.5 meters, 1.0 meters, and 1.5 meters), coastal decision-makers  now have a greater ability determine the potential inundation threats to  built infrastructure, sensitive natural resources, and special needs populations.  The resilience asseessment is a facilitated questionnaire.  It is a non-regulatory tool that is meant to help local decision-makers collaboratively  identify planning, mitigation, and adaptation opportunities to reduce vulnerability to coastal storms and sea level rise, building  capacity for coastal community resilience.  It is provides a starting point for a dialogue among various decision-makers, helping to spawn creative thinking and collaboration on ways to become more resilient for existing and future generations.  The questionnaire highlights the importance of local plan integration and consistency with municipal building codes and ordinances, and it identifies the importance of localized hazard assessments and the need to link them to planning, outreach, mitigation, response, and recovery. The report also discusses the Coastal Vulnerability Index.	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	 Completed Regional Or State Mid-Atlantic New Jersey Infrastructure Managed Ecosystems Natural Ecosystems Biota Social and Cultural Resources Economic Resources Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) Conservation/ Restoration of Sensitive Species and Habitats Physical Coastal and Oceanic Surface (Sea-surface temperature, sea level, salinity, ocean color, wave height) Forecasts and outlooks (monthly to annual, models)  Projections (intra-annual to multi-decadal, including SLR and model down-scaling) Plans, Assessments, Studies Maps (Imagery, geo-referenced data) Risk and Vulnerability Viewers and Web-based Tools Visualization tools (web-based, mapping programs)	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	New Jersey Coastal Community Vulnerability and Resilience Assessment Pilot	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	Office of Coastal Management, New Jersey Department of\r\nEnvironmental Protection\r\n\r\nGreenwich Township, Cumberland County, NJ	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	\N	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.nj.gov/dep/cmp/docs/ccvap-greenwich.pdf\r\n	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f

1273	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	\N	f	f	f	f	January 2013	f	f	f	From the Introduction: This National Climate Assessment collects, integrates, and assesses observations and research from around the country, helping to show what is actually happening and what it means for peoples’ lives, livelihoods, and future. This report includes analyses of impacts on seven selected sectors: human health, water, energy, transportation, agriculture, forests, and ecosystems and biodiversity. This report additionally focuses on the interactions among several sectors at the national level. It also assesses key impacts on the regions of the U.S.: Northeast, Southeast and Caribbean, Midwest, Great Plains, Southwest, Northwest, Alaska and the Arctic, Hawai‘i and the Pacific Islands; as well as coastal areas, oceans, and marine resources. Finally, this report is the first to explicitly assess the current state of adaptation, mitigation, and decision support activities.	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	 Ongoing Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) Sustainability of Marine Ecosystems Climate Impacts on Water Resources Changes in Extremes of Weather and Climate Conservation/ Restoration of Sensitive Species and Habitats National Natural Ecosystems Biota Managed Ecosystems Public Health and Safety Infrastructure Assess Climate and its Impacts Inform Mitigation and Adaptation Choices Plans, Assessments, Studies	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	National Climate Assessment Draft Report	t	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	t	f	National Climate Assessment and Development Advisory Committee	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://ncadac.globalchange.gov/	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	\N	f
325	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	NJ9	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	Kris Schantz, New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection, kschantz.ensp@embarqmail.com	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	The New Jersey Wildlife Action Plan (Plan) continues to be revised and refined for clarification and enhancement to ensure necessary conservation objectives are not overlooked. The New Jersey Department of Fish and Wildlife has been working with Rutgers University's Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy on a vulnerability assessment for the habitats in the Plan. The effort has been to assess the vulnerability of a sampling of the State’s habitats to the effects of climate change.  The process used a variety of proven metrics to rank habitats’ susceptibility to anticipated stressors, such as increased temperature, more severe storm events, and sea level rise.  The resulting ranking will be used to inform decision makers’ actions, including an upcoming revision to the State’s Wildlife Action Plan (WAP).  \r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	 Planned Regional Or State Mid-Atlantic New Jersey Managed Ecosystems Natural Ecosystems Biota Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) Conservation/ Restoration of Sensitive Species and Habitats Assess Climate and its Impacts Vulnerability assessments (species, habitats and community vulnerability assessments) Inform Mitigation and Adaptation Choices Plans, Assessments, Studies Risk and Vulnerability	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	New Jersey State Wildlife Action Plan Update\r\n	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection, Division of Fish and Wildlife \r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	\N	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.state.nj.us/dep/fgw/ensp/waphome.htm\r\n	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
485	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	t	S2	f	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	Robert Thieler, USGS, rthieler@usgs.gov	f	f	f	f	\N	t	t	t	The Coastal Vulnerability Index is designed to determine relative risks from future sea-level rise on the Atlantic, Pacific, and Gulf Coasts.  The CVI quanitifies the relative risk that physical changes will take place from sea-level rise based on various factors, including tidal range, wave height, coastal slope, shoreline change, geomorphology, and historical rate of relative sea-level rise. The approach combines vulnerabilty from sea-level rise and the systems ability to naturally adapt. 	t	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	\N	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	 Completed National Regional Or State New England Maine New Hampshire Massachusetts Vermont Connecticut Rhode Island Mid-Atlantic New York New Jersey Pennsylvania Marlyland Delaware Virginia District Of Columbia South East North Carolina South Carolina Infrastructure Built Coast (e.g., engineered solutions for shoreline protection) Natural Ecosystems Coasts Estuaries Wetlands (e.g., saltwater, brackish, freshwater; 486	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	S-5	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	\N	f	t	t	Being able to visualize potential impacts from sea level rise is a powerful teaching and planning tool, and the Sea Level Rise Viewer brings this capability to coastal communities. A slider bar is used to show how various levels of sea level rise will impact coastal communities. Completed areas include Mississippi, Alabama, Texas, Florida, and Georgia, with additional coastal counties to be added in the near future. Visuals and the accompanying data and information cover sea level rise inundation, uncertainty, flood frequency, marsh impacts, and socioeconomics. The Mid-Atlantic will be available in the Fall of 2012, and New England should be completed in 2013. 	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	 Ongoing National Regional Or State Delaware South Carolina Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) Downscale Climate Models Assess Climate and its Impacts Forecasts of Climate Conditions Physical Coastal and Oceanic Surface (Sea-surface temperature, sea level, salinity, ocean color, wave height) Depth and Elevation Data Projections (intra-annual to multi-decadal, including SLR and model down-scaling) Maps (Imagery, geo-referenced data) Viewers and Web-based Tools Visualization tools (web-based, mapping programs)	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	Sea Level Rise and Coastal Flooding Impacts Viewer	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	t	f	NOAA Coastal Services Center, on Digital Coast	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.csc.noaa.gov/digitalcoast/tools/slrviewer/index.html	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f

490	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	S7	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	Sept 2010	f	f	f	This document was developed to provide technical guidance to agencies, practitioners, and coastal decision-makers that want to use and/or collect geospatial data for sea level change assessments and mapping products.  The amount of information on sea-level rise can be difficult to navigate; thus, this document seeks to clarify existing data and information.  The document provides guidance on how to understand and apply this information to analysis and planning applications and directs readers to specific resources for various applications. This document compiles the most up-to-date and useful information from NOAA and other entities to provide access to a wide range of potential solutions to help with planning for sea level change. 	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	 National Climate Impacts on Water Resources Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) Improve Scientific Understanding of the Climate System and Essential Climate Variables Risk and Vulnerability Plans, Assessments, Studies Training and Capacity Building Adaptation and Mitigation Guidance, including Best Practices Manuals, Toolkits, and Guides	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	Technical Considerations for Use of Geospatial Data in Sea Level Change Mapping and Assessment	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	NOAA, Coastal Services Center	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	\N	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.csc.noaa.gov/digitalcoast/_/pdf/SLC_Technical_Considerations_Document.pdf	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
1309	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	Elizabeth Byers, West Virginia Division of Natural Resources, elizabeth.a.byers@wv.gov	f	f	f	f	2011	f	f	f	Abstract: This project assessed and ranked the relative climate change vulnerability of 185 animal\r\nand plant species in West Virginia. Most species were selected based on their status as Species\r\nof Greatest Conservation Need within the West Virginia Wildlife Conservation Action Plan.\r\nAmong the species identified in the state plan, priority was given to globally vulnerable or\r\nimperiled species identified by NatureServe (G1-G3), and selected species that are critically\r\nimperiled at the state level (S1). A small number of more common species were assessed. More\r\nthan half of the taxa assessed were scored as vulnerable to climate change. Amphibians were the\r\ntaxonomic group at highest risk, followed closely by fish, mollusks, and rare plants. Highly\r\nmobile taxonomic groups including birds and mammals appear to be somewhat less vulnerable,\r\nas are common and widespread habitat foundation plants. Obligate cave invertebrates are\r\npredicted to have strong resistance to climate change impacts.\r\nSpecies with high global Conservation Status Ranks (at risk throughout their range) are\r\nstatistically only slightly more vulnerable to climate change than globally abundant species.\r\nState-level Conservation Status Ranks and climate change vulnerability are more closely\r\ncorrelated, but scores for individual species still vary widely. In other words, rare species are not\r\nalways vulnerable to climate change, and common species are not necessarily resilient.\r\nSix of the twenty-three risk factors assessed were strongly correlated with vulnerability to\r\nclimate change across all taxonomic groups in the state. They are (a) natural barriers to\r\nmovement and dispersal, (b) anthropogenic barriers to movement and dispersal, (c) physiological\r\nthermal niche, (d) physiological hydrological niche, (e) genetic variation, and (f) modeled\r\nresponse.\r\nIn terms of the relative vulnerability of different geographies in the state, downscaled\r\nclimate models indicate that species in the northern part of the state may experience slightly\r\ngreater warming than those at the southern margin. Species dependent on moist habitats or\r\nephemeral streams and wetlands in the eastern and western portions of the state are likely to\r\nexperience greater drought stress than those in the higher-elevation Allegheny Mountains, but all\r\nhabitats are likely to face increased drought stress, especially during the summer and early fall.\r\nSpecies on the southern, or “trailing” edge of their global range are more likely to disappear from\r\nthe state. High elevation species restricted to the cool, moist summits and plateaus of Allegheny\r\nMountain region of the state are at increased risk because they have no possibility of migrating\r\nupward, and potential migration northward is blocked by significant low-elevation natural\r\nbarriers to the north.\r\nBased on the results of the assessment and review of current literature, management\r\nrecommendations were developed for consideration in the next revision of the West Virginia\r\nWildlife Conservation Action Plan. Key recommendations are to increase habitat connectivity;\r\nmanage for ecosystem function and habitat integrity; protect natural heritage resources; protect water quality and streamflow; aim for representation, resiliency, and redundancy; consider\r\ninnovative and unconventional strategies; reduce existing non-climate change ecosystem\r\nstressors; monitor, model, and adaptively manage; forge new partnerships; and mitigate.	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	 Completed Conservation/ Restoration of Sensitive Species and Habitats Changes in Extremes of Weather and Climate Regional Or State Mid-Atlantic Central West Virginia Natural Ecosystems Biota Assess Climate and its Impacts Vulnerability assessments (species, habitats and community vulnerability assessments) Plans, Assessments, Studies Vulnerability Assessment	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	Climate Change Vulnerability Assessment of Species of Concern in West Virginia. 	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	West Virginia Division of Natural Resources	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.wvdnr.gov/publications/PDFFiles/ClimateChangeVulnerability.pdf	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	\N	f

497	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	S12	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	jomalley@usgs.gov	f	f	t	f	\N	f	f	f	The USGS Coastal and Marine Geology Program (CMGP) National Assessment of Shoreline Change Web Mapping Application provides a national map view of short- and long-term shoreline change evaluations, and historical and modern shorelines. Clicking the appropriate data folder will expand or collapse the folder allowing the individual data layers to be displayed. Data layers may be "turned-off or on" by selecting the visible button beside the layer name. The map view will automatically update.	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	 Regional Or State New England Mid-Atlantic Data Stewardship and Provisions Viewers and Web-based Tools Completed Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) Inform Mitigation and Adaptation Choices Assess Climate and its Impacts Maps (Imagery, geo-referenced data)	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	National Assessment of Shoreline Change Web Mapping Application	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	USGS Coastal and Marine Geology Program (CMGP)	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://coastalmap.marine.usgs.gov/national/shorelc/	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
498	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	S13	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	Robert Thieler, USGS, rthieler@usgs.gov, (508) 457-2350	f	f	f	f	July 2011	f	f	f	The demands of increasing human population in the coastal zone create competition with coastal habitat preservation and with recreational and commercial uses of the coast and nearshore waters. As climate changes over the coming century, these problems facing coastal communities will likely worsen. Good management and policy decision-making require baseline information on the rates, trends, and scientific understanding of the processes of coastal change on a regional to national scale. To address this need, the U.S. Geological Survey is engaged in a research project of national scope to measure, report, and interpret historical shoreline change along open-ocean coasts of the United States. One of the primary goals of this project is to understand shoreline change hazards using methods that are comparable from one area of the country to another and that will allow for future, repeatable analyses of shoreline movement, coastal erosion, and land loss.	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	 National Natural Ecosystems Coasts Assess Climate and its Impacts Inform Mitigation and Adaptation Choices Plans, Assessments, Studies Risk and Vulnerability Impact Study Risk and Vulnerability Problem Focused	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	USGS Science for the Nation’s Changing Coasts: \r\nShoreline Change Research Fact Sheet	t	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	USGS	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://pubs.usgs.gov/fs/2011/3073/	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
751	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	EPAD30	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	Sep 2010 VT Agency of Natural Resources released the latest edition of Vermont's GHG Emissions Inventory Update. 499	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	f	S14	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	Robert Thieler, USGS, rthieler@usgs.gov, (508) 457-2350	f	f	f	f	2011	f	f	f	This project brings together scientists from the disciplines of geology, hydrology, geography, biology, and ecology to address the effects of sea-level rise (SLR) on the Nation’s coasts. The project synthesizes information on coastal environments and uncertainties in knowledge of coastal processes into a Bayesian statistical analysis framework. The Bayesian approach allows researchers to evaluate the probability of a number of sea-level rise impacts, and provides information that can be used for decision making.\r\nThe Bayesian statistical framework is ideal for using data sets derived from historical or modern observations such as long-term shoreline change or wetland accretion/elevation trends. This information can be combined with model simulations and used to define the relationships between key variables in coastal environments. A Bayesian Network provides a means of integrating these data to evaluate competing hypotheses regarding the relationships between forcing factors (e.g., rate of SLR, suspended sediment concentration, elevation change), and responses (e.g., shoreline change, wetland vertical accretion, water table change). This framework allows scientists to make probabilistic predictions of the future state of coastal environments for outcomes such as shoreline change, wetland survival, and changes in the depth to groundwater. The predictions also have estimates of outcome uncertainty that can be expressed as both numbers (e.g., 90%) and words (e.g., very likely). The ability to communicate SLR impacts in terms of a probabilistic prediction can improve scientists’ ability to support decision making and evaluate specific management questions about alternatives for addressing SLR. This information can also identify research needed to improve predictive skill.	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	 Completed National Natural Ecosystems Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) Assess Climate and its Impacts Inform Mitigation and Adaptation Choices Coastal and Oceanic Surface (Sea-surface temperature, sea level, salinity, ocean color, wave height) Physical Risk Assessment or Risk Management Climate Society Interactions Risk and Vulnerability Plans, Assessments, Studies Viewers and Web-based Tools Management Guidance (i.e. structured decision making) Training and Capacity Building Adaptation and Mitigation Guidance, including Best Practices Manuals, Toolkits, and Guides	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	Sea-level Rise Hazards and Decision Support	t	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	U.S. Geological Survey	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	\N	f	t	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://wh.er.usgs.gov/slr/index.html	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
1365	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	Mathias Collins, NOAA, mathias.collins@noaa.gov	f	f	f	f	2009	f	f	f	Abstract: Long-term flow records for watersheds with minimal human influence have shown trends in recent\r\ndecades toward increasing streamflow at regional and national scales, especially for low flow quantiles like the\r\nannual minimum and annual median flows. Trends for high flow quantiles are less clear, despite recent research\r\nshowing increased precipitation in the conterminous United States over the last century that has been brought\r\nabout primarily by an increased frequency and intensity of events in the upper 10th percentile of the daily precipitation\r\ndistribution – particularly in the Northeast. This study investigates trends in 28 long-term annual\r\nflood series for New England watersheds with dominantly natural streamflow. The flood series are an average of\r\n75 years in length and are continuous through 2006. Twenty-five series show upward trends via the nonparametric\r\nMann-Kendall test, 40% (10) of which are statistically significant (p < 0.1). Moreover, an average standardized\r\ndepartures series for 23 of the study gages indicates that increasing flood magnitudes in New England\r\noccurred as a step change around 1970. The timing of this is broadly synchronous with a phase change in the\r\nlow frequency variability of the North Atlantic Oscillation, a prominent upper atmospheric circulation pattern\r\nthat is known to effect climate variability along the United States east coast. Identifiable hydroclimatic shifts\r\nshould be considered when the affected flow records are used for flood frequency analyses. Special treatment of\r\nthe flood series can improve the analyses and provide better estimates of flood magnitudes and frequencies\r\nunder the prevailing hydroclimatic condition.	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	\N	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	 Completed Regional Or State New England Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) Climate Impacts on Water Resources Changes in Extremes of Weather and Climate Natural Ecosystems Assess Climate and its Impacts Forecasts of Climate Impacts  Inform Mitigation and Adaptation Choices Plans, Assessments, Studies Impact Study	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	Evidence for Changing Flood Risk in New England Since the Late 20th Century	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	NOAA	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1752-1688.2008.00277.x/abstract	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f

537	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	t	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	S21	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	t	\N	f	f	f	f	2009	f	f	f	The framework presented in this report may be used to categorize the relative vulnerability of species to climate change. There are four modules that compose this framework. These modules walk the user through a systematic process for (1) categorizing a species’ baseline vulnerability to extinction or major population reduction, (2) categorizing a species’ vulnerability to future climate change, (3) developing a matrix that gives an overall score of the species’ vulnerability to non-climate and climate change stressors, and (4) qualitatively determining the uncertainty in the estimate of a species’ vulnerability. \r\n	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	 Completed National Biota Endangered, Threatened, or Protected Species Terrestrial Candidate Species Species of Concern Conservation/ Restoration of Sensitive Species and Habitats Assess Climate and its Impacts Vulnerability assessments (species, habitats and community vulnerability assessments) Inform Mitigation and Adaptation Choices Ecological and Biological Plans, Assessments, Studies Impact Study Risk and Vulnerability Problem Focused Training and Capacity Building Management Guidance (i.e. structured decision making) Regulatory/ Policy Guidance	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	A Framework for Categorizing the Relative Vulnerability of Threatened and Endangered Species to Climate Change 	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	EPA	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	 http://cfpub.epa.gov/ncea/global/recordisplay.cfm?deid=203743	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
1364	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	Mathias Collins, NOAA, mathias.collins@noaa.gov	f	f	f	f	2012	f	f	f	Abstract: Recent studies document increasing precipitation and streamﬂow in the northeastern United\r\nStates throughout the 20th and early 21st Centuries. Annual peak discharges have increased over this period\r\non many New England rivers with dominantly natural streamﬂow – especially for smaller, more frequent ﬂoods.\r\nTo better investigate high-frequency ﬂoods (<5-year recurrence interval), we analyze the partial duration ﬂood\r\nseries for 23 New England rivers selected for minimal human impact. The study rivers have continuous records\r\nthrough 2006 and an average period of record of 71 years. Twenty-two of the 23 rivers show increasing trends\r\nin peaks over threshold per water year (POT⁄WY) – a direct measure of ﬂood frequency – using the MannKendall trend test. Ten of these trends had p < 0.1. Seventeen rivers show positive trends in ﬂood magnitude,\r\nsix of which had p < 0.1. We also investigate a potential hydroclimatic shift in the region around 1970.\r\nTwenty-two of the 23 rivers show increased POT⁄WY in the post-1970 period when comparing pre- and post-\r\n1970 records using the Wilcoxon rank-sum test. More than half of these increases have p < 0.1, indicating a\r\nshift in ﬂow regime toward more frequent ﬂooding. Region wide, we found a median increase of one ﬂood per\r\nyear for the post-1970 period. Because frequent ﬂoods are important channel-forming ﬂows, these results have\r\nimplications for channel and ﬂoodplain morphology, aquatic habitat, and restoration.	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	\N	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	 Completed Climate Impacts on Water Resources Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) National Regional Or State New England Natural Ecosystems Assess Climate and its Impacts Forecasts of Climate Impacts  Inform Mitigation and Adaptation Choices Plans, Assessments, Studies Impact Study Changes in Extremes of Weather and Climate	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	Increased Frequency of Low-Magnitude Floods in New England	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	NOAA	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://instaar.colorado.edu/uploads/publications/armstrong_etal_2012_increased_frequency_of_low-magnitude_floods_in_new_england.pdf	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f

541	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	S25	f	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	\N	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	t	Funded in part by the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act (ARRA) of 2009, as well as, direct funding from other federal, state and local entities, Photo Science is contracted by the United States Geological Survey (USGS) to collect and process LiDAR data for more than 8,000 square miles of the coastal zone and inland areas spanning six Northeastern states, including Maine, New Hampshire, Massachusetts, Connecticut, Rhode Island, and New York. Photo Science is tasked to provide project management, LiDAR data collection and processing, control surveys, product development, and quality control services.This project will not only help stimulate the U.S. economy and provide for more accurate floodplain mapping in the region, but will also represent the start of a regional LiDAR collection program that will be used as a test case for a national elevation program. The webinar features the USGS and Photo Science staff providing a technical overview of the project approach, specifications, deliverables and schedule as well as discuss the potential applications served by this high resolution elevation data set. The Maine Office of GIS will also provide background on the formation of the coalition of state and local agencies that banded together to secure the ARRA funding grant and move the project ahead with the USGS.	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	 Ongoing Completed Regional Or State New England Maine New Hampshire Massachusetts Vermont Connecticut Rhode Island Public Health and Safety Infrastructure Natural Ecosystems Coasts Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) Improve Scientific Understanding of the Climate System and Essential Climate Variables Assess Climate and its Impacts Inform Mitigation and Adaptation Choices Physical Coastal and Oceanic Geological Depth and Elevation Data Maps (Imagery, geo-referenced data) Viewers and Web-based Tools Visualization tools (web-based, mapping programs)	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	t	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	NEURISA: Northeast LiDAR Project	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	t	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	t	f	NEURISA	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	\N	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.neurisa.org/NE_LiDAR_Project	f	t	t	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
583	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	DS2	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	The goal of this study is to formalize an approach to inventory and analyze management decisions in order to produce useful information targeted toward effective adaptation to climate change. We began by: (1) selecting a study area and compiling a list of key decisions (2) developing criteria for evaluating the climate-relevance of decisions; (3) applying the criteria to select decisions that are potentially sensitive to climate change; (4) soliciting expert judgment regarding those selections (and refine the selections accordingly); and (5) testing alternative weighting schemes for prioritizing decisions most in need of decision support or additional research based on the selected attributes.	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	 Regional Or State Mid-Atlantic Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) Changes in Extremes of Weather and Climate Improve Scientific Understanding of the Climate System and Essential Climate Variables Assess Climate and its Impacts Inform Mitigation and Adaptation Choices Training and Capacity Building Management Guidance (i.e. structured decision making)	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	A Method to Assess Climate-Relevant Decisions: Application in the Chesapeake Bay 	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	EPA	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://cfpub.epa.gov/ncea/global/recordisplay.cfm?deid=227483 	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
761	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	DE5	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	\N	f	t	f	From the September 2011 Compendium: Coastal areas and natural resources are particularly vulnerable to climate change, especially with respect to accelerated sea level rise, shoreline erosion, increased storm frequency and intensity, changes in rainfall, and related flooding among other potential impacts. Investigation of such impacts, specifically marsh depletion and increased mudflats at Bombay Hook, will be conducted to determine patterns of sediment flux in or out of the depleted marsh area. Data collection will involve conducting river transects within the Leipsic River using the Acoustic Doppler Current Profiler (ADCP) and associated software to collect and process tide and current data. Water quality will also be monitored, specifically total sediment solids (TSS) to aid in determining sediment fluxes in or out of the depleted marsh area.\r\n\r\nThis study will result in a written report that includes a summary of results; discussion of data analysis and statistical procedures. Results will be used to predict future changes in marsh depletion and to help determine marsh management techniques to counteract these impacts affecting the tidal \r\nmarshes at Bombay Hook.	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	 Completed Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) Regional Or State Mid-Atlantic Delaware Natural Ecosystems Assess Climate and its Impacts Inform Mitigation and Adaptation Choices Coastal and Oceanic Surface (Sea-surface temperature, sea level, salinity, ocean color, wave height) Sub-surface (e.g., temperature, salinity, nutrients, carbon, phytoplankton) Physical Surveys and PreliminaryAssessments	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	Bombay Hook Hydrology/ Sediment Movement Study 	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	DNREC Delaware Coastal Programs, US Fish and Wildlife Service	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.dnrec.delaware.gov/coastal/Documents/SeaLevelRise/SLRCompSept2011.pdf	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
584	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	DS3	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	Informing Decisions in a Changing Climate examines the growing need for climate-related decision support--that is, organized efforts to produce, disseminate, and facilitate the use of data and information in order to improve the quality and efficacy of climate-related decisions. Drawing on evidence from past efforts to organize science for improved decision making, it develops guidance for government agencies and other institutions that will provide or use information for coping with climate change. This volume provides critical analysis of interest to agencies at every level, as well as private organizations that will have to cope with the world's changing climate. \r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	 Completed Regional Or State New England Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) Changes in Extremes of Weather and Climate Improve Scientific Understanding of the Climate System and Essential Climate Variables Inform Mitigation and Adaptation Choices Management Guidance (i.e. structured decision making)	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	Informing Decisions in a Changing Climate	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	National Research Council. 725	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	S22	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	General Contact Information: info@cleanair-coolplanet.org; 603.422.6464\r\n	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	Clean Air Cool Planet has recently completed a pilot project in which it commissioned state-of-the-art coastal vulnerability maps showing how the range of sea level rise predictions up to 2100 would impact coastal communities and infrastructure in eight cities on the Eastern seaboard and several more on the US Gulf coast. The maps online show projected sea-level rise for the Chesapeake Bay Region and the cities of Hampton, NH; Miami, FL; Norfolk, VA; Philadelphia, PA; Portland, ME; Tampa-St. Petersburg, FL; and Wilmington, NC.\r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	 Regional Or State New England Mid-Atlantic New Hampshire Maine Marlyland Virginia North Carolina South East Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) Assess Climate and its Impacts Forecasts of Climate Conditions Coastal and Oceanic Surface (Sea-surface temperature, sea level, salinity, ocean color, wave height) Physical Projections (intra-annual to multi-decadal, including SLR and model down-scaling) Viewers and Web-based Tools Visualization tools (web-based, mapping programs)	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	East Coast Sea-Level Rise Maps\r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	f	f	f	t	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	Clean Air Cool Plant\r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.cleanair-coolplanet.org/climate_preparedness/cv_maps.php#cbr	f	f	t	t	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
726	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	S24	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	\N	f	t	f	The MARCO Mapping and Planning Portal is an online tool that allows state, federal, and local decision-makers and the public to visualize, query, map, and analyze ocean and coastal data in the Mid-Atlantic region. The five MARCO states agreed to work together to develop a regional, web-based portal as part of their 2009 action plan. In response to this need, the Virginia Coastal Zone Management Program provided funding (through their CZM Award from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration- NOAA) for creation of this prototype mapping and planning portal for the Mid-Atlantic region. The portal was developed by a team of representatives from each of the Mid-Atlantic States, NOAA, and The Nature Conservancy.   The portal includes map data layers grouped into five broad categories:\r\nAdministrative (e.g. official boundaries)\r\nBiological (e.g. sea‐floor habitats)\r\nGeophysical (e.g. water depth, sediments)\r\nHuman Uses (e.g. fishing, shipping)\r\nDecision Support (e.g. overlays of various uses and natural features). The portal includes a sea-level rise vulnerability layer based on the coastal vulnerability index under the Geophysical category.	t	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	t	\N	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	 Regional Or State Mid-Atlantic New York New Jersey Marlyland Delaware Virginia District Of Columbia Infrastructure Energy Managed Ecosystems Fisheries Natural Ecosystems Biota Inland Habitats and Watersheds  Sustainability of Marine Ecosystems Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) Changes in Extremes of Weather and Climate Vulnerability assessments (species, habitats and community vulnerability assessments) Assess Climate and its Impacts Inform Mitigation and Adaptation Choices Ecological and Biological Vulnerability Assessment Risk and Vulnerability Plans, Assessments, Studies Viewers and Web-based Tools Visualization tools (web-based, mapping programs)	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	Mid-Atlantic Regional Council on the Ocean (MARCO) Portal\r\n	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	MARCO, Mid-Atlantic States, The Nature Conservancy (TNC)\r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	\N	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.midatlanticocean.org/map_portal.html	f	f	t	t	t	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
727	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	S25	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	Sam Merrill, smerrill@usm.maine.edu (207) 228-8596\r\n	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	COastal Adaptation to Sea level rise Tool (COAST) is an approach to assess the costs and benefits of adapting to sea-level rise scenarios developed by the New England Environmental Finance Center. This approach focuses on the cost of damage from sea-level rise and storm surges. This approach uses GIS and incorporates various sources of existing data, including U.S. Army Corps depth-damage functions,  NOAA's  Sea, Lake, and Overland Surges from Hurricanes (SLOSH), and other flood methods as well as sea-level rise scenarios, property values, and infrastructure costs. This tool is primarily meant for municipal planners.  Please see the entry under Maine for more information on it being used at a project level. \r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	 Completed Regional Or State Infrastructure Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) Assess Climate and its Impacts Risk Assessments Forecasts of Climate Impacts  Inform Mitigation and Adaptation Choices Risk and Vulnerability Plans, Assessments, Studies Viewers and Web-based Tools Prioritization Tools Monitoring tools (e.g. U.S. Drought Monitor) Visualization tools (web-based, mapping programs) Ongoing	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	t	COastal Adaptation to Sea level rise Tool (COAST)\r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	t	f	New England Environmental Finance Center (EFC) at the Muskie School of Public Service, University of Southern Maine\r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	\N	f	t	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://efc.muskie.usm.maine.edu/docs/coast.arcuser.pdf; http://efc.muskie.usm.maine.edu/pages/projects_cre.html\r\n	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
728	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	S26	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	Bruce Young, NatureServe, bruce_young@natureserve.org\r\n	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	The NatureServe Climate Change Vulnerability Index can help identify plant and animal species that are particularly vulnerable to the effects of climate change. Using the Index, you apply readily available information about a species’ natural history, distribution and landscape circumstances to predict whether it will likely suffer a range contraction, population reductions, or both during the coming years. You can use the Index as part of a variety of analyses, including assessing the relative risk of species listed in State Wildlife Action Plans or part of any assessment of the vulnerability of species to climate change.\r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	 Completed National Biota Conservation/ Restoration of Sensitive Species and Habitats Assess Climate and its Impacts Vulnerability assessments (species, habitats and community vulnerability assessments) Inform Mitigation and Adaptation Choices Plans, Assessments, Studies Risk and Vulnerability	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	Climate Change Vulnerability Index (CCVI)\r\n	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	NatureServe\r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.natureserve.org/prodServices/climatechange/ccvi.jsp\r\n	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f

1368	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	\N	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	\N	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	The State of the Gulf of Maine Report is a group of papers providing background information about the Gulf of Maine environment and issue papers discussing challenges identified by the Gulf of Maine Council as high priority. One of two theme papers discussing Climate Change impacts in the report, "Climate Change and its Effects on Ecosystems, Habitats and Biota" presents a discussion of driving forces, current trends, impacts and actions occurring in the Gulf of Maine. 740	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	EPAD14	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	April 2009, EPA released the national greenhouse gas inventory, indicating that overall emissions during 2007 increased by 1.4 percent from the 2006. The "Inventory of U.S. Greenhouse Gas Emissions and Sinks: 1990-2007", is the latest annual report submitted by the United States to the Secretariat of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, which sets an overall framework for governments internationally to address climate change.	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	 Completed Regional Or State National International Natural Ecosystems Atmospheric Climate Society Interactions Other Services	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	Inventory of U.S. Greenhouse Gas Emissions and Sinks: 1990-2007	t	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	EPA	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.epa.gov/climatechange/ghgemissions/usinventoryreport.html	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
733	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	EPAD5	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	Water is crucial for the economy. Virtually every industry from agriculture, electric power and\r\nindustrial manufacturing to beverage, apparel, and tourism relies on it to grow and ultimately\r\nsustain their business.\r\nYet water is becoming scarcer globally and every indication is that it will become even more\r\nso in the future. Decreasing availability, declining quality, and growing demand for water are\r\ncreating significant challenges to businesses and investors who have traditionally taken clean,\r\nreliable and inexpensive water for granted. These problems are already causing decreases\r\nin companies’ water allotments, shifts toward full-cost water pricing, more stringent water\r\nquality regulations, growing community opposition, and increased public scrutiny of corporate\r\nwater practices.\r\nThis Ceres/Pacific Institute report concludes that climate change will exacerbate these water\r\nrisks, especially as the world population grows by 50 million a year.	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	t	f	 Completed Climate Impacts on Water Resources Regional Or State National International Public Health and Safety Infrastructure Fresh Water Resources	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	Water Scarcity and Climate Change: Growing Risks for Businesses and Investors	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	CERES, Pacific Institute	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.pacinst.org/reports/business_water_climate/full_report.pdf	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	\N	f

735	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	EPAD9	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	March 2009	f	f	f	From the Executive Summary: Over the course of a year, through a process that engaged \r\nover 125 stakeholders and received input from over 200 citizens, the 29 members of Governor John Lynch’s Climate Change Policy Task Force developed this Climate Action Plan \r\nwhich is aimed at achieving the greatest feasible reductions in greenhouse gas emissions while also providing the greatest possible long-term economic benefits to the citizens of New Hampshire. The most significant reductions in both emissions \r\nand costs will come from substantially increasing energy efficiency in all sectors of our economy, continuing to increase sources of renewable energy, and designing our communities \r\nto reduce our reliance on automobiles for transportation. \r\nIn essence, a response to climate change and our economic \r\nfuture are inextricably tied to how we produce our energy \r\nand how much energy we use. Future economic growth in \r\nNew Hampshire as well as mitigation of, and adaptation to, \r\na changing climate will depend on how quickly we transition \r\nto a new way of living that is based on a far more diversified \r\nenergy mix, more efficient use of energy, and development \r\nof our communities in ways that strengthen neighborhoods \r\nand urban centers, preserve rural areas, and retain New \r\nHampshire’s quality of life. \r\n\r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	 Completed Regional Or State New England New Hampshire Public Health and Safety Infrastructure Energy Plans, Assessments, Studies	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	New Hampshire Climate Action Plan: A Plan for New Hampshire’s Energy, Environmental\r\nand Economic Development Future	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	New Hampshire Department of Environmental Services, New Hampshire Climate Change Policy Task Force	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://des.nh.gov/organization/divisions/air/tsb/tps/climate/action_plan/documents/nhcap_final.pdf	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
738	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	EPAD12	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	t	f	f	f	\N	t	f	f	Yale research report, "Climate Change in the American Mind: Americans' Climate Change Beliefs, Attitudes, Policy Preferences, and Actions." The report is based on a nationally representative survey of more than 2,000 Americans conducted in October and November.  In short, the study found that even in the midst of the growing economic crisis, over 90 percent of Americans said that the United States should act to reduce global warming, including 34 percent who said the U.S. should make a large-scale effort, even if it has large economic costs.  	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	 National Cross Disciplinary Climate Society Interactions Decision Making Communication and Education Other	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	Climate Change in the American Mind: Americans' Climate Change Beliefs, Attitudes, Policy Preferences, and Actions	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	Yale University	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://environment.yale.edu/climate/files/CC_American_Mind.pdf	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f

743	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	EPAD18	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	\N	t	t	f	f	\N	f	f	f	Adaptation: An Issue Brief for Business A World Business Council Report on Climate Adaptation.  The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC)\r\n\r\nFourth Assessment Report, 1 Climate Change 2007: Synthesis Report, forecasts that climate change will have significant impacts on populations and environments around the world. Furthermore, it is likely that in the absence of concerted efforts to mitigate greenhouse emissions, climate change will have negative effects on business and global markets. It will likely lead to a change in existing business models and current risk management structures. \r\n\r\nThis publication is focused on providing an overview of adaptation from a business perspective. It describes potential impacts of climate changes, risks and opportunities for business, and why business should consider adaptation planning and measures. It summarizes intergovernmental efforts to promote adaptation in vulnerable regions and highlights areas in which business could have a role in promoting adaptation, both at community and global levels.\r\n	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	t	f	 Completed International National Regional Or State Recreation and Tourism Social and Cultural Resources Economic Resources Cross Disciplinary Biota Natural Ecosystems Managed Ecosystems Infrastructure Public Health and Safety	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	Adaptation: An Issue Brief for Business	t	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	World Business Council	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	t	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.preventionweb.net/files/7781_Adaptation1.pdf	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f

752	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	EPAD32	f	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	\N	f	t	f	f	\N	f	f	f	June 2009 Carbon Solutions New England report titled "Economic & Greenhouse Gas Impacts of the New 2009 Fuel Economy (CAFE) Standards in New England". The results show that the New England region would see a net economic benefit of $10 billion by 2025 under the new fuel economy standards announced by President Barack Obama in May. The money would come from fuel savings and reinvestment back into the local and regional economy. The new fuel economy standards would also save 10 billion gallons of gasoline and avoid 88 million metric tons of CO2 emissions by 2025.  The report also details the savings by states in 6 separate state fact sheets.	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	 Completed Regional Or State National New England Mid-Atlantic Rhode Island Connecticut Vermont New Hampshire Massachusetts Maine Economic Resources Recreation and Tourism Social and Cultural Resources Social and Economic Climate Society Interactions Policy Planning Impact Study Plans, Assessments, Studies	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	Economic & Greenhouse Gas Impacts of the New 2009 Fuel Economy (CAFE) Standards in New England	t	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	Carbon Solutions New England	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	t	f	\N	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://carbonsolutionsne.org/resources/reports/pdf/2009_cafe_final.pdf	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f

748	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	EPAD23	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	t	f	f	\N	f	f	f	The American Clean Energy and Security Act of 2009 (“ACES” or the “Act”) discussion draft was released on March 31st by Rep. Waxman (Chairman, Energy & Commerce) and Rep. Markey (Chairman, Subcommittee on Energy & Environment)1. ACES sets forth an ambitious and comprehensive reform of U.S. climate and energy policy. The Act would build the foundation of a sustainable and efficient economy that will power our nation’s future and create millions of energy efficiency and clean energy jobs. The following document provides: (1) a brief summary of the Act; (2) initial ENE (Environment Northeast) reactions and suggestions; and (3) detailed section-by-section summaries. In addition to this document, ENE is preparing a separate explanation and analysis of the differences and similarities between cap and trade, cap and dividend, and carbon taxes.	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	 Completed National Public Health and Safety Infrastructure Social and Cultural Resources Economic Resources Education	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	Report, American Clean Energy and Security Act of 2009[H.R. 2454]	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	Environment Northeast	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.env-ne.org/public/resources/pdf/ENE_Waxman_Markey_Summary_041009.pdf	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
749	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	EPAD23	f	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	\N	f	f	f	f	\N	f	t	f	This report analyzes interstate variation in per capita emissions, seeking to explain why some states have much\r\nlower emissions than others. Some of the differences are based on objective factors beyond anyone’s control: for\r\ninstance, the coldest states have high heating needs, while the hottest states use a lot of air conditioning. Other\r\ndifferences may be based on policies and measures that have lowered emissions in some states, and could be\r\nreplicated in others. Identifying the causes of interstate differences in emissions may also help clarify the\r\npotential regional impacts of policies, such as a cap and trade system, which put a price on carbon emissions.	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	 Completed Regional Or State New England Mid-Atlantic Central Great Lakes South East South Carolina North Carolina Ohio West Virginia District Of Columbia Virginia Delaware Marlyland Pennsylvania New Jersey New York Rhode Island Connecticut Vermont Massachusetts New Hampshire Maine Viewers and Web-based Tools Management Guidance (i.e. structured decision making) Regulatory/ Policy Guidance	f	f	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	t	t	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	Greenhouse Gases and the American Lifestyle: Understanding Interstate Differences in Emissions	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	t	t	f	t	f	\N	f	f	t	f	f	Ecotrust, Economics for Equity and the Environment, Stockholm Environment Institute Report	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	\N	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.e3network.org/papers/NRDC_state_emissions_report.pdf	f	t	t	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	\N	f
754	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	EPAD34	t	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	t	f	f	\N	f	f	f	The report summarizes the science and the impacts of climate change on the United States, now and in the future. It focuses on climate change impacts in different regions of the U.S. and on various aspects of society and the economy such as energy, water, agriculture, and health. It’s also a report written in plain language, with the goal of better informing public and private decision making at all levels.\r\n\r\nIn addition to discussing the impacts of climate change in the U.S., the report also highlights the choices we face in response to human-induced climate change. It is clear that impacts in the United States are already occurring and are projected to increase in the future, particularly if the concentration of heat-trapping greenhouse gases in the atmosphere continues to rise. So, choices about how we manage greenhouse gas emissions will have far-reaching consequences for climate change impacts. Similarly, there are choices to be made about adaptation strategies that can help to reduce or avoid some of the undesirable impacts of climate change. This report provides many of the scientific underpinnings for effective decisions to be made – at the national and at the regional level. \r\n\r\n	f	f	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	 Completed National Public Health and Safety Infrastructure Energy Fresh Water Resources Communication and Commerce Transportation Built Coast (e.g., engineered solutions for shoreline protection) Managed Ecosystems Agriculture Natural Ecosystems Biota Social and Cultural Resources Recreation and Tourism Economic Resources Assess Climate and its Impacts Improve Scientific Understanding of the Climate System and Essential Climate Variables	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	Global Climate Change Impacts in the United States	t	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	Global Change Research Progam	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	http://www.globalchange.gov/publications/reports/scientific-assessments/us-impacts	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
