757	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	DE1	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	Gabrielle C. Lyons, Delaware Coastal Programs, Department of Natural Resources & Environmental Control, gabrielle.lyons@state.de.us	f	f	f	f	\N	f	t	f	The purpose of the Marsh Vulnerability Index (MVI) is to develop a health index for Spartina alterniflora in salt marshes.  Real-Time Kinematic GPS was used to attain elevation data for S. alterniflora to determine the elevational growth range. LiDAR was used during project design to ensure a representative elevation range was sampled. The MVI classifies healthy, degrading, and severely degrading short-form Spartina alterniflora marsh regions .\r\n\r\nThe MVI will be essential for evaluating wetland vulnerability to sea-level rise on a watershed or statewide basis, while also enabling the strategic placement of monitoring resources to enhance efforts to understand the future evolution and migration potential of Delaware’s tidal wetlands, as well as promiting conservation and restoration. MVI classification optimizes the monitoring efforts and resources to the highest levels possible, so the broadest extent of Delaware’s tidal wetlands may be evaluated and managed.  The MVI also classifies healthy and degrading short-form Spartina alterniflora marshes based on a correlation between degrading marshes and low elevations. With success, the MVI can be used in Mid-Atlantic States for regional comparison and planning.	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	 Completed Conservation/ Restoration of Sensitive Species and Habitats Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) Regional Or State Mid-Atlantic Delaware Natural Ecosystems Wetlands (e.g., saltwater, brackish, freshwater; tidal/non-tidal) Assess Climate and its Impacts Vulnerability assessments (species, habitats and community vulnerability assessments) Inform Mitigation and Adaptation Choices Coastal and Oceanic Surface (Sea-surface temperature, sea level, salinity, ocean color, wave height) Plans, Assessments, Studies Risk and Vulnerability	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	Delaware Tidal Marsh Vulnerability Index	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	Delaware Department of Natural Resources and Environmental Conservation	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	\N	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.dnrec.delaware.gov/Admin/DelawareWetlands/Documents/Conference%20presentations/Siok_Marsh%20Vulnerability%20Index%20(MVI)_DE%20Wetlands%20Conf%202010.pdf \r\n	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	t	\N	f
758	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	DE2	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	Delaware Coastal Programs, 302-739-9283	f	f	f	f	\N	f	t	f	This document provides an overview of the projects initiated under Delaware's Sea-Level Rise Initiative, relating to data and modeling, hazard planning, monitoring, outreach and eduction, etc.  The projects described in the compendium all have been initiated under the Sea Level Rise Initiative to help to build partnerships and capacity, increase resiliency, increase public knowledge of and support for actions to reduce our vulnerability and make decisions based upon the best available science.	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	 Completed, Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) Regional Or State Mid-Atlantic Delaware Other Managed Ecosystems Infrastructure Natural Ecosystems Biota, project report	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	Delaware Sea-Level Rise Initiative Compendium September 2011	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	Delaware Department of Natural Resources and Environmental Conservation	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.dnrec.delaware.gov/coastal/Documents/SeaLevelRise/SLRCompSept2011.pdf\r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
759	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	f	DE3	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	\N	f	t	f	f	\N	f	t	f	To help assess, prepare for and minimize the potential impacts of sea level rise, the Delaware Coastal Programs Section of the Delaware Department of Natural Resources and Environmental Control is leading a multi-year Sea Level Rise Initiative.  The goal of the Sea Level Rise Initiative is to reduce Delaware’s future vulnerability to the effects of sea level rise.  This will be accomplished by: providing scientific and technical support for decision-making, implementing on-the-ground project in partnership with stakeholders, providing educational and outreach opportunities for stakeholders and the public, improving existing policies and management practices and/or developing new policies and management practices where necessary.    \r\nThe Sea Level Rise Initiative is designed to be iterative and will grow and \r\nchange as new data, outreach and policy needs are identified.  Part of this initiative is developing a Sea-Level Rise Adaptation Plan. The Initiative website includes all relevant activities as does the 2011 Compendium.	f	f	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	 Ongoing Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) Regional Or State Mid-Atlantic Delaware Public Health and Safety Infrastructure Managed Ecosystems Natural Ecosystems Biota Social and Cultural Resources Economic Resources Assess Climate and its Impacts Vulnerability assessments (species, habitats and community vulnerability assessments) Conservation/ Restoration of Sensitive Species and Habitats Improve Scientific Understanding of the Climate System and Essential Climate Variables Inform Mitigation and Adaptation Choices Promote Public Climate Literacy Coastal and Oceanic Climate Society Interactions Physical Coastal and Oceanic Surface (Sea-surface temperature, sea level, salinity, ocean color, wave height) Maps (Imagery, geo-referenced data) Projections (intra-annual to multi-decadal, including SLR and model down-scaling) Plans, Assessments, Studies Vulnerability Assessment Engagement Engagement	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	Delaware Sea-Level Rise Initiative	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	t	f	Delaware Coastal Management Program	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.dnrec.delaware.gov/coastal/Pages/SeaLevelRiseAdaptation.aspx\r\n	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
760	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	DE4	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	t	f	f	\N	f	t	f	Scientists from Delaware Coastal Programs used a model to develop maps to show the possible impacts of inundation based on various Sea Level Rise scenarios for Delaware’s waterways and the land that surrounds them (watersheds). These maps reflect the filling of these watersheds at constant elevations also referred to as "Bath Tub" modeling. In other words, the maps show the water levels rising in the watersheds similar to the “filling of a bathtub”.   These maps  represent a constant,  watershed based,  water level and  do not include any changes in water level due to the distance from tidal forcing, downstream flow, or other factors  which could possibly change water levels.  There are various uses for these maps including: assessing and planning land use and zoning ordinances to protect community resources while guiding new development; developing emergency management plans to prepare for natural disasters like nor’easters or tropical storms; determining impacts to the economy such as changes to the business and tourism sectors; conserving wildlife, wetlands, beaches, and other natural resources; protecting recreational areas like fishing spots, boating areas, parks, and cultural heritage locations; developing future plans for infrastructure like roads, fire departments, schools, sewer systems, drinking water, etc.; managing agriculture practices to conserve working farm lands and protect irrigation sources; and planning for coastal community resiliency by determining hazards and vulnerabilities.	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	 Completed Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) Regional Or State Mid-Atlantic Delaware Public Health and Safety Infrastructure Managed Ecosystems Natural Ecosystems Social and Cultural Resources Economic Resources Assess Climate and its Impacts Inform Mitigation and Adaptation Choices Physical Coastal and Oceanic Surface (Sea-surface temperature, sea level, salinity, ocean color, wave height) Maps (Imagery, geo-referenced data) Projections (intra-annual to multi-decadal, including SLR and model down-scaling)	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	Delaware Sea-Level Rise Inundation Maps	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	Delaware Coastal Programs	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.dnrec.delaware.gov/Pages/SLRMaps.aspx	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
764	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	DE8	f	f	t	f	f	t	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	\N	f	t	f	This map shows potential flooding, or inundation, caused by sea level rise. Use the slider bar to view the extent.   The map illustrates the scale of potential flooding, not the exact location, and does not account for erosion, subsidence, or future construction. Water levels are shown as they would appear during an average high tide (mean high water). Rising sea levels will cause daily high tides to reach farther inland.	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	 Completed Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) Regional Or State Mid-Atlantic Delaware Assess Climate and its Impacts Forecasts of Climate Conditions Physical Coastal and Oceanic Surface (Sea-surface temperature, sea level, salinity, ocean color, wave height) Projections (intra-annual to multi-decadal, including SLR and model down-scaling) Viewers and Web-based Tools	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	Sea Level Rise Impacts for Wilmington, Delaware (Map)	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	NOAA Coastal Services Center, the U.S. Geological Survey, and the Delaware Department of Natural Resources	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.csc.noaa.gov/de_slr/\r\n	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
1388	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	2013	f	f	t	f	f	f	t	t	Jon Hare, NOAA NEFSC, Jon.Hare@noaa.gov	f	f	f	f	Published 2012	f	t	f	Scientists from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and University of North Florida examined thermal factors of range limits for gray snapper using field observations and laboratory experiments.  This thermal factor (juvenile mortality during winter) was then combined with IPCC general circulation models to predict changes in species range under various climate scenarios.  Results indicate that gray snapper distribution will shift northward under all scenarios.  Authors indicate that refining these range predictions will involve addressing uncertainty associated with the thermal tolerance variable, and identify improvements of these types of biological parameters as a major research need.	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	t	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	 Completed Sustainability of Marine Ecosystems Conservation/ Restoration of Sensitive Species and Habitats Regional Or State New England Mid-Atlantic Maine New Hampshire Massachusetts Rhode Island South East North Carolina South Carolina Marlyland New York Delaware Connecticut Virginia New Jersey Managed Ecosystems Fisheries Natural Ecosystems Oceans Assess Climate and its Impacts Forecasts of Climate Impacts  Ecological and Biological Population Projections (intra-annual to multi-decadal, including SLR and model down-scaling)	f	f	f	f	t	t	f	f	f	t	t	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	Projecting Range Limits with Coupled Thermal Tolerance - Climate Change Models: An Example Based on Gray Snapper (Lutjanus griseus) along the U.S. East Coast	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	t	t	t	f	t	f	\N	f	t	f	f	f	NOAA Northeast Fishery Science Center (NEFSC), University of Florida	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	\N	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.plosone.org/article/info%3Adoi%2F10.1371%2Fjournal.pone.0052294	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
791	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	EPAD45	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	This nation's coasts and oceans contribute much to the United States economy. For the past ten years, the National Ocean Economics Program (NOEP) has compiled time-series data that track economic activities, demographics, natural resource production, non-market values, and federal expenditures in the U.S. coastal zone both on land and in the water. In June 2009, NOEP released its first national level report of the U.S. ocean and coastal economies.	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	 Completed Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) National Regional Or State Economic Resources Climate Society Interactions Social and Economic Plans, Assessments, Studies	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	State of the U.S. Ocean and Coastal Economies 2009	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	National Ocean Economics Program (NOEP)	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.oceaneconomics.org/NationalReport/	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
767	f	f	t	f	f	t	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	DE11	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	Danielle Kreeger, Partnership for the Delaware Estuary, DKreeger@Delaware Estuary.org.	f	f	f	f	June 2010	f	t	f	The Delaware Estuary watershed and its natural resources will face a variety of challenges with climate change. Due to the many unique features of the Estuary,\r\nsome aspects of changing climate may not be as severe here as in nearby watersheds and estuaries, whereas other changes may be more important. Since 2008, the Partnership for the Delaware Estuary has engaged experts from throughout the region to conduct an assessment of the vulnerabilities and adaptation options for three key resources of the Delaware Estuary: tidal\r\nwetlands, drinking water, and bivalve shellfish. These provide three case studies – a habitat case study, a human/water use case study, and a living resource case study – for looking at climate change impacts and how best to adapt to them here in the Delaware Estuary. These case studies represent the very first step in an adaptation planning process, the goal of which is to ensure the resiliency of this vast and valuable system as climate changes.   For all three case studies, the top concerns among experts are the vulnerabilities of key resources to sea‐level rise and salinity changes, and flooding and precipitation effects. Whereas, many estuaries around the world are concerned with sea‐level rise, the vulnerability to salinity rise in the Delaware Estuary is somewhat unique, and especially notable because this system has the world’s largest freshwater tidal prism. Adaptation actions are outlined for each resource as well.  	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	 Completed Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) Climate Impacts on Water Resources Conservation/ Restoration of Sensitive Species and Habitats Regional Or State Mid-Atlantic Delaware Infrastructure Managed Ecosystems Natural Ecosystems Biota Recreation and Tourism Assess Climate and its Impacts Vulnerability assessments (species, habitats and community vulnerability assessments) Inform Mitigation and Adaptation Choices Physical Coastal and Oceanic Surface (Sea-surface temperature, sea level, salinity, ocean color, wave height) Sub-surface (e.g., temperature, salinity, nutrients, carbon, phytoplankton) Plans, Assessments, Studies Adaptation/Action Plan Risk and Vulnerability Engagement	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	Climate Change and the Delaware Estuary	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	Partnership for the Delaware Estuary	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	t	t	\N	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.delawareestuary.org/science_projects_climate_ready_products.asp	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	f	f	\N	f

Findings Much energy infrastructure lies in areas that are predicted to become increasingly physically unstable; as a result of scheduled decommissioning, revised environmental standards, stimulus spending and new development, there is likely to be substantial investment in new energy infrastructure; it is critical that new and existing infrastructure be designed or retrofitted for changing environmental conditions.	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	 Completed Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) National Regional Or State Infrastructure Energy Inform Mitigation and Adaptation Choices	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	The Vulnerability of Energy Infrastructure to Environmental Change	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	Chatham House and DOE's Global Energy & Environment Strategic Ecosystem (GlobalEESE)	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.chathamhouse.org/publications/papers/view/-/id/737	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f

1400	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	2013	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	2011	f	f	f	 Published in 2011 in ICES Journal of Marine Science.  Summarized from the abstract: The North Atlantic Oscillation (NAO) and Atlantic Multidecadal Oscillation (AMO) (indices of atmospheric variability and long-term sea surface temperature, respectively) were used to develop a model examining climate influences on Georges Bank cod recruitment.  A simple Cushing-type model was developed, and then expanded to include climate influences.  The resulting auto-regressive-integrative-moving average (ARIMA) type model (ARIMAX) produced reliable forecasts, and it is recommended that it be implemented in short term prediction for Georges Bank cod assessments and forecasts, as well as management strategies.	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	t	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	 Completed Sustainability of Marine Ecosystems Regional Or State New England Maine Massachusetts New Hampshire Managed Ecosystems Fisheries Forecasts and outlooks (monthly to annual, models)  Hindcasts (climatologies, models)	f	f	f	f	t	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	Broad-scale Climate Influences on Cod (Gadus morhua) Recruitment on Georges Bank	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	Federal Research Institute for Rural Areas, Institute for Sea Fisheries; NOAA NMFS (National Marine Fisheries Service)	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://icesjms.oxfordjournals.org/content/68/3/592.full.pdf+html	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
781	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	DE12	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	Partnership for the Delaware Estuary, Info@DelawareEstuary.org, 302-655-4990 \r\n	f	f	f	f	June 2010	f	t	f	The report describes a new approach to climate adaptation planning that draws from the assessment of natural resource damages associated with oil spills and other episodic  events.  The analytic framework couples the wetland change modeling in SLAMM (Sea Level Affecting Marshes Model) with traditional damage assessment methods via habitat equivalency analysis (HEA).   The report estimates gains and losses in the ecological service flows provided by coastal habitats as well as the type and size of projects necessary to maintain current wetland services.  Potentially, these projects can be either restoration of degraded habitats or preventative measures taken to avoid future loss.  The framework in the report can be used for identifying and valuing the cost of efforts to address potential changes in wetlands habitats	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	\N	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	 Completed Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) Mid-Atlantic Regional Or State Delaware Natural Ecosystems Coasts Estuaries Wetlands (e.g., saltwater, brackish, freshwater; tidal/non-tidal) Beaches Assess Climate and its Impacts Vulnerability assessments (species, habitats and community vulnerability assessments) Forecasts of Climate Impacts  Inform Mitigation and Adaptation Choices Projections (intra-annual to multi-decadal, including SLR and model down-scaling) Risk and Vulnerability Plans, Assessments, Studies	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	Application of Ecological and Economic Models of the Impacts of Sea-Level Rise to the Delaware Estuary 	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and Partnership for the Delaware Estuary	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	\N	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.delawareestuary.org/pdf/Climate/IEc-%20Delaware%20Estuary%20SLAMM%20HEA%20-%20June%202010.pdf\r\n	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	t	\N	f
795	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	EPAD51	f	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	\N	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	Sep 15, 2009 - ISO New England Inc. released the results of a study evaluating renewable resource potential in the region and beyond, as well as the economic and environmental impacts of that development. The New England Governors' Renewable Energy Blueprint found that significant amounts of potential wind resources could be added to New England's system provided appropriate transmission expansion is in place. The report also found that offshore wind resource integration offers the most cost-effective use of new and existing transmission and that annual wholesale electric energy prices will be generally lower with the addition of renewable resources that have low or no fuel costs, such as wind energy.	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	 Completed National Regional Or State New England Maine New Hampshire Massachusetts Vermont Connecticut Rhode Island Public Health and Safety Infrastructure Energy	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	The New England Governors' Renewable Energy Blueprint	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	ISO New England Inc.	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	\N	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.nescoe.com/uploads/September_Blueprint_9.14.09_for_release.pdf	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
787	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	DE19	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	Austin Kane, Science and Policy Manager, National Wildlife Federation, kanea@nwf.org	f	f	f	f	\N	f	t	f	The National Wildlife Federation (NWF) worked with the Northeast region’s conservation community on planning for climate change and conducting climate change vulnerability analyses as well as helping plan and implement on-the-ground projects that take climate change into consideration.  This document is part of a project designed to generate climate-smart guidance for restoration and management projects to safeguard fish, wildlife, and their habitats from the impacts of climate change.   This coastal climate-smart guidance is an initial step to provide wildlife and natural resource managers  practical tools for ensuring that current and future projects are maximizing benefits to ecosystems and critical species. NWF convened an expert panel to develop a process for defining climate-smart conservation for the coastal system and to provide climate-smart options that natural resource managers could consider when planning and implementing projects. The panel selected two project types in the coastal environment on which to focus: coastal impoundments and living shorelines.  The coastal impoundment information was based significantly on the efforts of Delaware DFW to plan for sea-level rise and implement pilot adaptation projects to address sea-level rise impacts on their coastal impoundments.  	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	 Completed Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) Regional Or State Mid-Atlantic Delaware Managed Ecosystems Natural Ecosystems Biota Assess Climate and its Impacts Vulnerability assessments (species, habitats and community vulnerability assessments) Inform Mitigation and Adaptation Choices Training and Capacity Building Adaptation and Mitigation Guidance, including Best Practices Manuals, Toolkits, and Guides Other, report	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	Practical Guidance for Coastal Climate-Smart Conservation Projects in the Northeast Case Examples for Coastal Impoundments and  Living Shorelines	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	National Wildlife Federation	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.nwf.org/~/media/PDFs/Global-Warming/Climate-Smart-Conservation/Final%20coastal%20climate-smart%20guidance%20document.ashx\r\n	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f

783	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	DE14	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	Robert W. Scarborough, Ph.D., DNREC, DSWC, Delaware Coastal Programs, Bob.Scarborough@state.de.us	f	f	f	f	February 2009	f	t	f	Prime Hook NWR is in the process of updating its Comprehensive Conservation Plan.   Part of the refuge are coastal impoundments that are threatened by sea-level rise and storms.  As a part of this update, the Refuge is integrating climate change into its management alternatives.  To do so, the NWR is using the Sea-Level Rise Affecting Marshes Model.  The Delaware Coastal Programs assisted the Refuge in  using the model to predict the land cover changes due to sea level rise. This report includes a description of the model, the results of the modeled scenarios, and an explanation of the deviations from a similar modeling effort done for the region.	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	 Completed Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) Regional Or State Mid-Atlantic Delaware Natural Ecosystems Assess Climate and its Impacts Vulnerability assessments (species, habitats and community vulnerability assessments) Forecasts of Climate Impacts  Inform Mitigation and Adaptation Choices Physical Coastal and Oceanic Surface (Sea-surface temperature, sea level, salinity, ocean color, wave height) Maps (Imagery, geo-referenced data) Projections (intra-annual to multi-decadal, including SLR and model down-scaling) Other, report	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	Application of the Sea Level Rise Affecting Marsh Model (SLAMM) Using High Resolution Data\r\nAt Prime Hook National Wildlife Refuge	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	U.S. Fish and Wildlife Agency	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.dnrec.delaware.gov/coastal/Documents/PHNWR%20SLAMM.pdf\r\n	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
788	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	MA1	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	Wesley Shaw, Lead Developer, wes@blueurchin.com	f	t	f	f	\N	f	f	f	Storm Smart Coasts is an online tool designed to help decision-makers address impacts from storms, flooding, sea-level rise, and climate change in coastal communities.  It is a resource that is a network of state and local sites that gives coastal decision makers  place to find and share the best resilience-related resources available, and the website provides collaboration tools. Federal sponsors include the EPA and the NOAA Coastal Services Center and the Northeast Regional Ocean Council is also a sponsor.  States involved include Massachusetts, New Hampshire, and Rhode Island.  New York, Connecticut, and Delaware will soon be a part of the network. The Massachusetts services include information on planning for storm events and hazards, including mitigation information, regulatory information, infrastructure services, emergency services etc. The site also includes information related to events during and after a storm. A new tool called Coastal Community Health And Resource Management (CHARM) is also on the Massachusetts site. \r\n	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	 Completed Changes in Extremes of Weather and Climate Regional Or State New England Massachusetts Infrastructure Public Health and Safety Recreation and Tourism Economic Resources Social and Cultural Resources Inform Mitigation and Adaptation Choices Promote Public Climate Literacy Engagement Training and Capacity Building Viewers and Web-based Tools	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	StormSmart Communities Massachusetts	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	NOAA, EPA, and Northeast Regional Ocean Council 	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	t	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://ma.stormsmart.org/\r\n	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
796	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	EPAD52	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	Jeri Weiss	t	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	EPA Releases Report on Reducing GHG Emissions through Land and Materials Management - report that finds significant potential to reduce the country’s greenhouse gas emissions through materials management (e.g., recycling and waste prevention) and land management (e.g., brownfield redevelopment, land restoration, and smart growth). This document offers a new perspective on opportunities to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. The report, “Opportunities to Reduce Greenhouse Gas Emissions through Materials and Land Management Practices,” finds that 42 percent of U.S. greenhouse gas emissions are influenced by materials management policies. 	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	 Completed National Regional Or State New England Public Health and Safety Infrastructure Urban Cross Disciplinary	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	Reducing GHG Emissions through Land and Materials Management	t	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	EPA	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	http://www.epa.gov/oswer/docs/ghg_land_and_materials_management.pdf	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
789	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	MA2	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	John O'Leary, Massachusetts Division of Fish and Wildlife,john.oleary@state.ma.us	f	f	f	f	April 2010	f	f	f	This report is the second product that is part of project carried out by Manomet Center for Conservation Sciences and the Massachusetts Division of Fish and Wildlife to help advance adaptation planning in the state related to the State Wildlife Action Plan. This project was funded by the Wildlife Conservation Society/Doris Duke.  This report includes the results of a vulnerability assessment of fish and wildife and their habitats to climate change.  The questions answered in this report include: How do the SWAP-targeted fish and wildlife habitats rank in terms of their likely comparative vulnerabilities to climate change?;   How will the representation of these habitats in Massachusetts be altered by a changing climate?;  Which vertebrate Species in Greatest Need of Conservation are likely to be most vulnerable to climate change?; and What degree of confidence can be assigned to the above predictions? An expert panel was formed to answer these questions and conduct the assessment and 20 habitats were analyzed.  Species of Greatest Conservation Need were also assessed.  	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	 Completed Regional Or State New England Massachusetts Managed Ecosystems Natural Ecosystems Biota Assess Climate and its Impacts Vulnerability assessments (species, habitats and community vulnerability assessments) Inform Mitigation and Adaptation Choices Plans, Assessments, Studies Vulnerability Assessment	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	Climate Change and Massachusetts Fish and Wildlife: Volume 2 Habitat and Vulnerability 	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	Massachusetts Division of Fish and Wildlife, Manomet Center for Conservation Sciences	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.mass.gov/dfwele/dfw/habitat/cwcs/pdf/climate_change_habitat_vulnerability.pdf \r\n	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f

1399	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	2013	f	f	f	f	t	f	t	t	\N	f	f	f	f	2012-	f	t	f	In 2011, the National Resources Defense Council petitioned to have river herring (alewife and blueback herring, collectively) listed as a threatened species under ESA.  River herring are anadromous, and thus susceptible to marine and inland impacts; they are considered an important prey species for atlantic cod, striped bass, and flounder.  It was concluded that a series of workshops and assessments were necessary to determine the health of river herring populations.  NOAA invited expert presenters and the public to a series of workshops in 2012, one of which discussed climate change impacts, as well as identified data gaps and research needs; workshop proceedings were compiled into a report. For more information about NOAA NMFS activities related to river herring, visit: http://www.nero.noaa.gov/prot_res/CandidateSpeciesProgram/RiverHerringSOC.htm.	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	 Ongoing Sustainability of Marine Ecosystems Conservation/ Restoration of Sensitive Species and Habitats Regional Or State New England Maine New Hampshire Massachusetts Connecticut Rhode Island Mid-Atlantic New York New Jersey Marlyland Delaware Virginia South East North Carolina South Carolina Managed Ecosystems Fisheries Natural Ecosystems Oceans Inland Habitats and Watersheds  Biota Species of Concern Plans, Assessments, Studies	f	f	f	f	t	t	f	f	f	t	t	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	River Herring Climate Change Workshop Report. 306	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	RI1	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	Wesley Shaw, Lead Developer, wes@blueurchin.com.\r\n	f	t	f	f	\N	f	f	f	Storm Smart Communities is an online tool designed to help decision-makers address impacts from storms, flooding, sea-level rise, and climate change in coastal communities.  It is a resource that is a network of state and local sites that gives coastal decision makers  place to find and share the best resilience-related resources available, and the website provides collaboration tools. Federal sponsors include the EPA and the NOAA Coastal Services Center and the Northeast Regional Ocean Council is also a sponsor.  States involved include Massachusetts, New Hampshire, and Rhode Island.  New York, Connecticut, and Delaware will soon be a part of the network. The Rhode Island services include information on planning for storm events and hazards, including mitigation information, regulatory information, infrastructure services, emergency services etc. The site also includes information related to events during and after a storm.  \r\n	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	 Ongoing Completed Regional Or State New England New Hampshire Massachusetts Rhode Island Public Health and Safety Infrastructure Social and Cultural Resources Economic Resources Changes in Extremes of Weather and Climate Inform Mitigation and Adaptation Choices Promote Public Climate Literacy Engagement Training and Capacity Building Viewers and Web-based Tools	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	StormSmart Communities Rhode Island\r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	t	f	NOAA, EPA, and Northeast Regional Ocean Council \r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	\N	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://ma.stormsmart.org/\r\n	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f

817	f	f	t	f	f	t	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	MA4	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	Vandana Rao, Asst. Director for Water Policy Executive Office of Energy and Environmental Affairs, vandana.rao@state.ma.us	f	t	f	f	September 2011	f	f	f	The Massachusetts Legislature passed the Global Warming Solutions Act and it was signed in 2008.  It directed the secretary of Energy and Environmental Affairs (EEA) to convene an advisory committee to develop a report, analyzing adaptation strategeis for projected climate changes. This report is by the Massachusetts Climate Change \r\nAdaptation Advisory Committee, and it is organized into two parts. Part I includes an overview of the observed and predicted changes to Massachusetts‘ climate and their anticipated impacts, key findings, a set of guiding principles, and key adaptation strategies, cutting across multiple sectors.  The second part of the report is organized into five  sections, including coastal zone and oceans as well as natural resources and habitat, key infrastructure, human health and welfare, and local economy and government. Each section includes a description of the vulnerabilities to climate change and  adaptation strategies that could help increase resilience and preparedness.  The coastal section focuses on the open ocean, bays, estuaries, salt marshes and tidal flats.  This section outlines vulnerabilities and adaptation strategies relating to land protection, policy, management and restoration, and monitoring.  The report also includes a section specific to wetlands, including coastal wetlands. Vulnerabilities relate to changes in temperature and precipitation, and adaptation strategies are identified relating to land protection, policy, management and restoration, and monitoring.	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	 Completed Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) Changes in Extremes of Weather and Climate Regional Or State New England Massachusetts Public Health and Safety Infrastructure Managed Ecosystems Natural Ecosystems Biota Social and Cultural Resources Economic Resources Assess Climate and its Impacts Vulnerability assessments (species, habitats and community vulnerability assessments) Inform Mitigation and Adaptation Choices Sustainability of Marine Ecosystems Climate Impacts on Water Resources Conservation/ Restoration of Sensitive Species and Habitats Plans, Assessments, Studies Adaptation/Action Plan Recreation and Tourism	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	Massachusetts Climate Change Adaptation Report	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	Executive Office of Energy and Environmental Affairs and the Adaptation Advisory Committee	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	t	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	www.mass.gov/environment/cca \r\n	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	f	f	\N	f
815	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	EPAD65	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	Over the last decade, a growing body of evidence indicates that soot and smoke from incomplete combustion are major contributors to climate change. Black carbon, a soot component, is a potent climate driver that absorbs sunlight in the atmosphere, changes rainfall patterns, and when deposited on snow and ice, accelerates melting. In addition, soot can cause direct effects on health and agriculture. Climate and other effects of soot are magnified in broad regions where the strongest source emissions occur, but transported soot is also a major concern in the Arctic. The short atmospheric lifetime of soot particles also means that emissions reductions produce nearly immediate results, in contrast to most greenhouse gases (GHGs).	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	 Completed Changes in Extremes of Weather and Climate National Public Health and Safety Inform Mitigation and Adaptation Choices	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	BLACK CARBON: A Science/Policy Primer	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	\r\nPEW Center on Global Climate Change	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.c2es.org/publications/black-carbon-primer	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
1406	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	2013	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	Rochelle Sturtevant, Regional Sea Grant Extension Educator, Rochelle.Sturtevant@noaa.gov	f	f	f	t	\N	t	f	f	Climate Ready Great Lakes is a project built to assist with climate change adaptation in the Great Lakes region. 824	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	EPAD79	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	Recent Spatially Explicit Mapping of Hurricane Risk in New England 2010. Hurricanes are one of the major natural disturbances affecting human livelihoods in coastal zones worldwide. Assessing hurricane risk is an important step toward mitigating the impact of tropical storms on human life and property. This study uses NOAA’s historical tropical cyclone database (HURDAT or ‘best-track’), geographic information systems, and kernel smoothing techniques to generate spatially explicit hurricane risk maps for New England.	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	 Completed Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) Changes in Extremes of Weather and Climate Regional Or State New England Public Health and Safety Improve Scientific Understanding of the Climate System and Essential Climate Variables	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	Spatially Explicit Mapping of Hurricane Risk in New England 2010	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	Yale School of Forestry and Environmental Studies	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.springerlink.com/content/52343nn803261233/fulltext.pdf?MUD=MP	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f

828	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	EPAD85	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	The American Water Works Association (AWWA) and American Society of Mechanical Engineers Innovative Technologies Institute, LLC (ASME-ITI) announced recently the development of the first risk and resilience management standard designed specifically for water utilities. \r\nThe J100 standard, created in response to 9/11, Hurricane Katrina and other recent disasters, will be released July 1, 2010. The Risk Analysis and Management for Critical Asset Protection (RAMCAP) method is designed to help water and wastewater utilities identify potential threats to U.S. water infrastructure and prepare for or mitigate damage.	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	f	f	f	f	 Completed Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) Climate Impacts on Water Resources Changes in Extremes of Weather and Climate National Public Health and Safety Emergency Management Indirect Climate Hazards Water Quality Infrastructure Fresh Water Resources Wastewater Water Supply Storm Water Plans, Assessments, Studies Risk and Vulnerability Training and Capacity Building Adaptation and Mitigation Guidance, including Best Practices Manuals, Toolkits, and Guides	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	The Risk Analysis and Management for Critical Asset Protection (RAMCAP)	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	The American Water Works Association (AWWA) and American Society of Mechanical Engineers Innovative Technologies Institute, LLC	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	\N	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.awwa.org/standardJ100	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	t	t	f	f	\N	f
829	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	EPAD87	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	As the U.S. Congress has struggled\r\nto pass comprehensive climate change legislation,\r\nobservers in the United States and abroad have\r\nasked what greenhouse gas emissions reductions are\r\npossible under existing federal laws and through state\r\naction. Can the U.S. meet the Obama Administration’s\r\nCopenhagen commitment to reduce greenhouse gas\r\nemissions in the range of 17 percent below 2005 levels\r\nby 2020 using the regulatory tools already available\r\nto federal agencies, together with announced actions\r\nat the state level? Even if congressional action is\r\nultimately necessary to put the U.S. on a long-term\r\nlow-carbon path and aid in the transition to a lowcarbon\r\neconomy, can federal agencies and state\r\ngovernments get the U.S. started down that path? To\r\nhelp answer these and related questions, the World\r\nResources Institute (WRI) presents this analysis of\r\npotential reductions under existing federal authorities\r\nand announced state actions through 2030.	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	 Completed National Infrastructure Energy Transportation Economic Resources Management Guidance (i.e. structured decision making) Regulatory/ Policy Guidance	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	Reducing GHG Emission in the US Using Existing Authorities & State Action	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	World Resources Institute	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	http://pdf.wri.org/reducing_ghgs_using_existing_federal_authorities_and_state_action_summary.pdf	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f

837	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	EPAD94	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	\N	t	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	"A Human Health Perspective on Climate Change"- A Report released on 4/22/10 outlining the Research Needs on the Human Health Effects of Climate Change published by Environmental Health Perspectives and the National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences. 839	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	EPAD96	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	International Research Institute for Climate & Society 2010 Report "Assessment of Intraseasonal to Interannual Climate Prediction and Predictability". Intraseasonal to interannual (ISI) climate forecasts make up the middle ground between what you might think of as a classic weather forecast — one that typically looks out over the next several days — and global climate change simulations that look at trends in long-term climate out to the end of the 21st century. More specifically, ISI forecasts focus on weekly, monthly, seasonal, and annual timescales. These timescales are important for planning in sectors like water resource management, agriculture, and energy.	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	 Completed Ongoing International National Regional Or State Forecasts and outlooks (monthly to annual, models)  Hindcasts (climatologies, models) Projections (intra-annual to multi-decadal, including SLR and model down-scaling)	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	Assessment of Intraseasonal to Interannual Climate Prediction and Predictability	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	t	f	International Research Institute for Climate & Society 2010 Report	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://dels.nas.edu/Report/Assessment-Intraseasonal-Interannual-Climate/12878	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
840	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	EPAD97	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	\N	t	t	f	f	\N	f	f	f	Accelerated climate change is anticipated to have wide-ranging effects on the future sustainability of the Earth due to adverse ecological,\r\nsocial and economic impacts (Stern 2006; McMullen and Jabbour 2009). 2e\r\ndriving force is an increase in the Earth’s temperature as a result of human activities\r\n(e.g., release of greenhouse gases and changes in landscape characteristics).\r\n2e Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) projects a global mean\r\ntemperature increase of 1.1°C to 6.4°C by 2100, which is likely to a3ect storms\r\nand 4oods, and lead to a rise in sea level due to the thermal expansion of the\r\noceans and the melting of ice sheets and glaciers (IPCC 2007a). Recent research\r\ne3orts estimate a global sea level rise of between 50 cm and 190 cm from 1990 to\r\n2100 (see Vermeer and Rahmstorf 2009). 2ere are several parts of the Gulf of\r\nMaine coast line that are classi5ed as highly sensitive to the impacts of sea level\r\nrise because of risks associated with storm events. 2e physical extent of climaterelated\r\nimpacts will vary depending on regional and local situations (Burtis 2006).\r\nCoastal communities in the Gulf of Maine will be impacted in numerous ways,\r\nincluding: health and well-being of communities (e.g., injury, mortality, migration,\r\ncrime and security); access to services; design and placement of structures\r\n(e.g., buildings, bridges, and utilities); cost of living; loss of livelihoods, and the\r\ncumulative magnitude of climate change impacts (see Figure 1). Climate change\r\nmitigation and adaptation are becoming increasingly important to community\r\nmanagement and there are numerous ongoing federal, provincial/state, county,	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	t	f	 Completed International Canada Regional Or State New England Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) Changes in Extremes of Weather and Climate Sustainability of Marine Ecosystems Conservation/ Restoration of Sensitive Species and Habitats Public Health and Safety Infrastructure Managed Ecosystems Natural Ecosystems Biota Social and Cultural Resources Recreation and Tourism Economic Resources Cross Disciplinary	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	Climate Change and Its Effects on Humans	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	Gulf of Maine Council	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	t	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.gulfofmaine.org/state-of-the-gulf/docs/climate-change-and-its-effects-on-humans.pdf	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
841	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	EPAD99	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	Recent U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) climate studies in New England have shown substantial evidence of hydrologic changes during the last 100 years, including trends toward earlier snowmelt runoff, decreasing occurrence of river ice, and decreasing winter snowpack. These studies are being expanded to include investigation of trends in groundwater levels and fluctuations. Groundwater is an important drinking-water source throughout northern New England (Maine, New Hampshire, and Vermont). The USGS is currently investigating whether or not groundwater recharge from snowmelt and precipitation exhibits historical trends. In addition to trend-testing, groundwater resources also will be analyzed by relating groundwater-level changes to the large year-to-year variability in weather conditions.\r\n\r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	 Completed Ongoing Climate Impacts on Water Resources National Regional Or State New England Maine New Hampshire Vermont Fresh Water Resources Infrastructure Managed Ecosystems	f	f	f	f	t	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	Quantifying Effects of Climate Change on the Snowmelt- Dominated Groundwater Resources of Northern New England	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	t	f	USGS	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://pubs.usgs.gov/fs/2010/3104/	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	\N	f
844	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	EPAD102	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	The Interim Report of the Interagency Ocean Policy Task Force (September\r\n2009) calls for strengthening the nation’s capacity to observe the nation’s\r\noceans, coastal waters and Great Lakes. IOOS®, established by law in\r\nMarch of 2009 and referred to in the statute as the Integrated Coastal Ocean\r\nObserving System, provides the framework for developing such a system.\r\nThe Act establishes a federal-regional partnership for understanding the unique\r\ncharacteristics of the nation’s diverse regions, integrating existing information\r\nfrom federal and non-federal sources, and expanding the observation network\r\nto fill critical gaps. IOOS® is a partnership of 17 Federal agencies and\r\n11 Regional Associations for Coastal Ocean Observing (RAs).\r\nThe need for more comprehensive and higher resolution data and information\r\nabout our coasts and Great Lakes has never been greater. Climate change,\r\nocean acidification, declining fish stocks, expanding dead zones, and the\r\nincreasing and sometimes conflicting uses of our coastal waters for food,\r\ntransportation, energy, mineral resources and recreation require an expanded\r\nnetwork of observations, enhanced analyses and understanding, and improved predictive and forecasting capabilities.	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	 Completed Ongoing Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) Sustainability of Marine Ecosystems Regional Or State National Public Health and Safety Managed Ecosystems Infrastructure Natural Ecosystems Maps (Imagery, geo-referenced data) Projections (intra-annual to multi-decadal, including SLR and model down-scaling) Hindcasts (climatologies, models)	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	Providing Coastal Information in a Changing Climate	t	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	t	f	National Federation of Regional Associations For Coastal and Ocean Observing	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.usnfra.org/documents/03.10_RCBooklet_lo-res.pdf	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f

846	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	EPAD107	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	t	f	f	\N	f	f	f	This report responds to the requirements of Section 9506 of the Omnibus Public Lands Act [Public Law (PL) 111–11; Appendix A] calling for a report to Congress that describes the impacts of global climate change on freshwater resources of the United States, and identifies key actions to improve the Nation’s capacity to detect and predict changes in freshwater resources that are likely to result from a changing climate. 845	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	EPAD103	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	Anthony Leiserowitz, Yale University,Anothony.leiserowitz@yale.edu\r\nNicholas Smith, Yale University, nicholas.smith@yale.edu	t	f	f	f	\N	t	f	f	Knowledge of Climate Change Across Global Warming's Six Americas report includes results from a national study of what the American public understands about how the climate system works, and the causes, impacts and potential solutions to global warming. Prior research has identified six distinct audiences within the American public (the Alarmed, Concerned, Cautious, Disengaged, Doubtful, Dismissive) that each respond to global warming in very different ways. \r\nThis report describes how knowledge of climate change varies across these different groups. 	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	 Completed National Cross Disciplinary Climate Society Interactions Decision Making	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	Knowledge of Climate Change Across Global Warming’s Six Americas	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	Yale Project on Climate Change and Communication	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://environment.yale.edu/climate/files/Knowledge_Across_Six_Americas.pdf	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f

847	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	EPAD108	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	\N	t	t	f	f	\N	f	f	f	his report, made possible with generous support from the Barr Foundation, represents the first in-depth look at how Massachusetts residents perceive the problem posed by global warming, as well as their willingness to embrace efforts to address this unprecedented challenge.\r\n\r\n	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	 Completed Regional Or State New England Massachusetts Public Health and Safety Infrastructure Managed Ecosystems Natural Ecosystems Biota Social and Cultural Resources Recreation and Tourism Economic Resources Cross Disciplinary Plans, Assessments, Studies Engagement Education	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	The 80 Percent Challenge: A Survey of Climate Change Opinion and Action in Massachusetts	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	MassInc	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	t	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.massinc.org/Research/The-80-percent-challenge.aspx	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
850	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	EPAD112	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	The spring (March-May) of 2011, particularly April, brought extreme weather and climate events to many parts of the United States. Tornadoes, flooding, drought, and wildfires ravaged many parts of the country during the period, and each of these extremes broke long-standing records and have been compared to the 'worst such cases' in history. While similar extremes have occurred throughout modern American history, never before have they occurred in a single month. According to the Storm Prediction Center (SPC), there were 751 tornadoes during April alone, and the confirmed number of tornadoes surpassed the all-time monthly record of 542 tornadoes set in May 2003. Record rainfall along the Ohio River Valley, punctuated with snowmelt across the upper Midwest, caused record flooding along the mid and lower Mississippi River, with water levels surpassing the historic floods of 1927 and 1937. Above-normal precipitation and vegetative growth during 2010, followed by dry and windy conditions the first five months of 2011, created ideal wildfire conditions across the Southern Plains where millions of acres of land burned. According to the U.S. Drought Monitor (USDM), the same region experienced Extreme-to-Exceptional [D3-D4] drought following consecutive months that were record to near-record dry.	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	 Completed Changes in Extremes of Weather and Climate National Regional Or State South East Great Lakes Central Mid-Atlantic New England Viewers and Web-based Tools Hindcasts (climatologies, models) Maps (Imagery, geo-referenced data)	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	Spring 2011 U.S. Climate Extremes	t	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	NOAA, National Climatic Data Center	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/special-reports/2011-spring-extremes/	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
854	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	Mathias Collins, NOAA, mathias.collins@noaa.gov	f	f	f	f	2011	f	f	f	From the report: Flood frequency estimates are used to quantify the magnitude and\r\nfrequency of relatively rare or extreme river discharges. Such estimates are\r\nnecessary to design many river restoration projects. For projects that include\r\nconstructing new infrastructure or retrofitting existing infrastructure flood\r\nfrequency estimates are required to size the infrastructure to withstand\r\nfloods of specified magnitudes (e.g., events expected to recur every 100\r\nyears). For projects where infrastructure is being removed and a natural\r\nchannel restored (e.g., a dam removal) flood frequency estimates are\r\nalso useful because stream channel geometry, process, and habitat are\r\nvery closely linked with the magnitude of comparatively frequent flood\r\nevents—those with recurrence intervals between 1 and 5 years. Thus, flood\r\nfrequency estimates are necessary to understand how channel changes will\r\naffect stream biota and adjacent floodplain landowners.	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	 Completed Climate Impacts on Water Resources  Managed Ecosystems Fisheries Natural Ecosystems Biota Infrastructure Fresh Water Resources Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) Regional Or State New England Infrastructure Assess Climate and its Impacts Forecasts of Climate Impacts  Inform Mitigation and Adaptation Choices Plans, Assessments, Studies Impact Study	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	Flood Frequency Estimates for New England River Restoration Projects:\r\nConsidering Climate Change in Project Design	f	t	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	NOAA Fisheries Service	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.habitat.noaa.gov/pdf/flood_frequency_estimates.pdf	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	\N	f
852	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	EPAD114	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	The problem is that the world is getting most of the energy its economies need in ways that are wrecking the climate its environment needs.	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	 Completed National Public Health and Safety Infrastructure Plans, Assessments, Studies Engagement Education Training and Capacity Building Management Guidance (i.e. structured decision making) Regulatory/ Policy Guidance	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	Climate‐Change Science and Policy: What Do We Know? Holdren, Assistant to the President for Science and Technology\r\nand Director, Office of Science and Technology Policy\r\nExecutive Office of the President of the United States	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.whitehouse.gov/sites/default/files/microsites/ostp/jph-kavli-9-2010.pdf	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
853	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	EPAD115	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	Cities across the United States should anticipate significant water-related vulnerabilities based on current carbon emission trends because of climate change, ranging from water shortages to more intense storms and floods to sea level rise. To help cities become more resilient to the rising threats of climate change, NRDC reviewed more than 75 scientific studies and other reports to summarize the water-related vulnerabilities in 12 cities across the United States. Although there may still be some uncertainty about what particular impacts threaten cities and how quickly or severely they might occur, action at the local level is the most effective method of reducing, mitigating, and preventing the negative effects of water-related climate change outlined in this fact sheet. NRDC urges cities to prepare for coming challenges relating to water resources. Fortunately, there are steps cities are already taking to become more resilient.\r\n\r\n	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	 Completed National Climate Impacts on Water Resources Infrastructure Fresh Water Resources Plans, Assessments, Studies Engagement Education Training and Capacity Building	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	Thirsty for Answers: Preparing for the Water-related Impacts of Climate Change in American Cities\r\n	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	National Resource Defense Council (NRDC)	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.nrdc.org/water/thirstyforanswers.asp	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	\N	f

857	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	EPAD122	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	Large-scale climate patterns influenced temperature\r\nand weather patterns around the globe in 2011. In particular,\r\na moderate-to-strong La Niña at the beginning of the\r\nyear dissipated during boreal spring but reemerged during\r\nfall. The phenomenon contributed to historical droughts\r\nin East Africa, the southern United States, and northern\r\nMexico, as well the wettest two-year period (2010–11)\r\non record for Australia, particularly remarkable as this\r\nfollows a decade-long dry period. Precipitation patterns\r\nin South America were also influenced by La Niña. Heavy\r\nrain in Rio de Janeiro in January triggered the country’s\r\nworst floods and landslides in Brazil’s history.\r\nThe 2011 combined average temperature across global\r\nland and ocean surfaces was the coolest since 2008, but\r\nwas also among the 15 warmest years on record and\r\nabove the 1981–2010 average. The global sea surface\r\ntemperature cooled by 0.1°C from 2010 to 2011, associated\r\nwith cooling influences of La Niña. Global integrals\r\nof upper ocean heat content for 2011 were higher than\r\nfor all prior years, demonstrating the Earth’s dominant\r\nrole of the oceans in the Earth’s energy budget. In the\r\nupper atmosphere, tropical stratospheric temperatures\r\nwere anomalously warm, while polar temperatures\r\nwere anomalously cold. This led to large springtime\r\nstratospheric ozone reductions in polar latitudes in both\r\nhemispheres. Ozone concentrations in the Arctic stratosphere\r\nduring March were the lowest for that period since\r\nsatellite records began in 1979. An extensive, deep, and\r\npersistent ozone hole over the Antarctic in September\r\nindicates that the recovery to pre-1980 conditions is\r\nproceeding very slowly.	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	f	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	 Completed Changes in Extremes of Weather and Climate International National Hindcasts (climatologies, models) Engagement Plans, Assessments, Studies Training and Capacity Building Education	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	State of the Climate in 2011	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	NOAA- American Metoerological Center	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www1.ncdc.noaa.gov/pub/data/cmb/bams-sotc/climate-assessment-2011-lo-rez.pdf	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
859	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	EPAD124	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	The effects of climate change are already impacting our water and wastewater utilities-- those entities entrusted with supplying our communities, our industries, and our natural envrionment with essential water management services. \r\n\r\nWater is the most important natural resource necessary for stable economic growth, as well as for human and environmental health. Our nation's water and wastewater infrastructure enables our prosperity by delivering clean water to our homes and industries and by transporting wastewater for treatment. 860	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	EPAD125	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency(EPA) have released “Achieving Hazard-Resilient Coastal & Waterfront Smart Growth: Coastal and Waterfront Smart Growth and Hazard Mitigation Roundtable Report.” The report presents an overview of a 2011 meeting where experts from the fields of smart growth, hazard mitigation, climate change adaptation, and coastal management shared ideas on how coastal and waterfront communities could improve quality of life, use land and other resources efficiently, and create environmentally and economically sustainable neighborhoods while minimizing risks from natural hazards related to coastal and waterfront flooding. 863	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	EPAT10	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	New CC tool from the Nature Conservancy. The outputs of the site are color coded maps of climate change over a specific area. It allows one home in on a particular area, like Lake Champlain, and there are several cells that cover the lake, One can pick a GCM scenario (there are several to choose from) and pick the version (hi, med, low) of the intensity of the change. As for variables, it's temperature and precipitation, month by month or season by season, and there are two periods of projections along with the current situation as modeled (for a base line). One can pick the projected temperature and precipitation or the change that the projection represents from the baseline.	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	\N	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	 Completed Ongoing Changes in Extremes of Weather and Climate National Projections (intra-annual to multi-decadal, including SLR and model down-scaling) Forecasts and outlooks (monthly to annual, models)  Maps (Imagery, geo-referenced data) Viewers and Web-based Tools Visualization tools (web-based, mapping programs)	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	Climate Wizard	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	t	f	Nature Conservancy	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.climatewizard.org/	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f

873	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	EPAT16	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	t	f	f	\N	f	f	f	"Climate Adaptation Knowledge Exchange" (CAKE) is a joint project of Island Press and EcoAdapt. It is aimed at building a shared knowledge base for managing natural systems in the face of rapid climate change. CAKE brings together EcoAdapt’s recognized leadership in developing the concepts and practices of climate adaptation with Island Press’s 27 years as the leading publisher of solutions-based environmental information to offer the most valuable, up-to-date, and authoritative materials on the subject. Just as importantly, it is intended to help build an innovative community of practice. It helps users to get beyond the limitations of their time and the unwieldy thicket of books, papers and articles.	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	 Completed Ongoing Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) National Regional Or State Managed Ecosystems Natural Ecosystems Recreation and Tourism Biota Social and Cultural Resources Maps (Imagery, geo-referenced data) Plans, Assessments, Studies Projections (intra-annual to multi-decadal, including SLR and model down-scaling) Forecasts and outlooks (monthly to annual, models)  Hindcasts (climatologies, models)	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	Climate Adaptation Knowledge Exchange (CAKE)	t	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	t	f	Island Press and EcoAdapt	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	t	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://www.cakex.org/	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
866	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	EPAT11	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	NOAA Coastal Services Center's Coastal Climate Adaptation Website focuses on adaptation-related resources, such as local and state plans, new policies, case studies, risk and vulnerability assessments, and decision-support tools. The Web site provides one location for access to numerous resources for states and communities to address climate change impacts and develop their own plans. The site is also building a community of practice on coastal climate adaptation via a forum where users can suggest new resources, engage in dialog on the issues, and submit comments and questions, providing a mechanism for climate and coastal management communities to engage on the topic.	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	 Completed Ongoing Coasts and Climate Resilience (including sea-level rise) National Regional Or State Infrastructure Public Health and Safety Education Engagement Training and Capacity Building Viewers and Web-based Tools Managed Ecosystems Natural Ecosystems Biota	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	NOAA Coastal Services Center's Coastal Climate Adaptation Website	t	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	t	f	NOAA Coastal Services Center	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	t	t	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	http://collaborate.csc.noaa.gov/climateadaptation/default.aspx	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f

876	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	EPAT39	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	\N	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	Ocean Health Index: The Index is the first comprehensive, annual assessment of the benefits that a healthy ocean provides through 10 goals, which emphasize the human-ocean relationship. The analysis, which was led by Dr. Ben Halpern and engaged 65 scientists and experts, was just released online in Nature .  The paper reports that the overall global score is 60 out of a sustainable state scored at 100, indicating that this relationship is out of balance and unsustainable.  Country-specific and goal-specific scores as well as a wealth of information on ocean health are provided at www.oceanhealthindex.org. 	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	 Sustainability of Marine Ecosystems Conservation/ Restoration of Sensitive Species and Habitats International National Regional Or State Engagement Education Training and Capacity Building Viewers and Web-based Tools	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	Ocean Health Index	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	Ocean Health Index	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	\N	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	www.oceanhealthindex.org	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	\N	f
927	f	f	f	f	f	t	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	f	R17	f	f	t	f	f	f	t	f	Pam Rubinoff, Rhode Island Sea Grant, rubi@crc.uri.edu\r\n	f	f	f	f	February 2008	f	t	f	This report includes results of a review of state coastal programs that have incorporated or are planning to incorporate sea-level rise into their planning and regulatory processes or are engaging in efforts related to climate change, sea-level rise, or coastal hazards.
